reviewText:
Introduction
I want to try and tell to english-speaking audience why I like this game, an why they should (or should not) play it.
First of all - for some people in ex-USSR countries this game is something like half-life 3 for everyone - we waited it long enough to be happy to get it. Even if it's not perfect, it's still what we waited so long.
Well, where to start. Once apon a time in the year of 2007, on anonymous imageboard 2ch.ru (now closed) one of the visitors posted a picture he draw, of a young girl with blonde hair. People liked it, so he draw more pictures of her. Later, he moved to another imageboard, and with other talented people decided to make a game. It should have been an adult game with USSR-attributes, becase many people grown-up while there was USSR, and had a good memories about their youth.
Well, it was easier to decide than to do. They started. And there was a lot of promises. A lot of waiting. A lot of drama. Changes in the team. Leaking of not ready game. A LOT OF EVERYTHING. So, when, after all this years, game was published to steam, a lot of people was like Wow! They really did it!".
Now

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer is a visual novel that was developed by a group of enthusiasts over a long span of five years. You could call it russian Katawa Shoujo because those games have similar origin: while KS was developed by anons from ♥♥♥♥♥, ES originated from iichan - one of main russian imageboards (the game itself at first was called 'iichan eroge'). But when Four Leaf Studios explore themes of maturing, entering the adult world and self-identity in society, iichan eroge team took a different, rather specific path. And that path will define whether you will like this game or not.

Point is, Everlasting Summer plays on your sense of nostalgia. But only if you have something to relate it to. Have you ever been in summer camps? Have you ever been that geeky mediocre guy with little to none friends whose only superpower is being invisible to girls? Have you ever felt that you wasted your youth chatting/s--tposting with anonymous strangers online? Have you ever felt that you need to change something in your life but you need a little push? Well, then this game is for you. Strap on and prepare for FEELs trip.

In terms of quality, Everlasting Summer proves that 'amateur' doesn't mean bad. Even by professional standards, music by Sergey Eybog and 'Between August and September' and background art by ArceniXC in this game are outstanding. Sprites and event CGs are lagging behind, but still aren't bad. The only thing I didn't like is extra route that tries to tie everything together and explain some plotholes but it is clear that the scriptwriter tried to jump over his head - that explanation is confusing, boring, out of place and totally uncalled for.

Overall this is a great game and you should definitely give it a chance, be you new to visual novels or a hardcore VN-otaku fluent in moonspeak.

At this point, I can't say anything about translation because I played this game right after release in 2013 when there was no english translation (well, not that I would when russian is my native language). But I'll give it a try and update my review.

In Soviet Russia game plays you!

Thumbs up:

P.S. I can't guarantee you would like this game, but it's totally worth to try.

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer is a free-to-play animesque visual novel, created by Soviet Games.

The game has a pretty standart gameplay as far as visual novels go: there is a static picture that depicts your current surroundings, character sprites are placed on that picture, you read dialogues, sometimes you get to make a decision. There are few notable exceptions to that rule, but this is generally what you would expect from the game.

Everlasting Summer is extremely story-rich, one playthrough has an average span of seven in-game days, each day takes aproximately one-two hours to read through. There is an average number of 5 decisions to make per day that do have an impact on the story (so much there are actually 13 endings to discover). On top of that, ending of Day 5 and the following days are completely unique to the ending you're heading to. You will have to play through all of them to discover all secrets of the story.

Story itself starts out like this: protagonist is a young man in his early 20s named Semyon (Sam). He's has almost no social life. He lives on his parents' money. He spends all day in the internet. He has no will to change anything.
One day he takes a bus that for some reason takes him through time to 80s, to a pioneer camp Sovionok" ("Owlet"). Semyon then has to find answers. Why did he end up here? How to get out of this place? Does he even need to get out of here...?

Most of the time you interact with 10 very well written characters that may or may not have a secret agenda related to your situation. The game packs a train of feels that it will happily unleash on you. Guilttrips
date:
ahoy!

Let me give you a list of pros and cons:

+ Interesting non-linear multi-ending story
+ Heavy emotional investment is guaranteed
+ Amazing soundtrack
+ Beautiful scenery and well-drawn character sprites
+ A lot of references to russian culture

reviewText: Everlasting Summer is a visual novel, produced by Soviet Games, that tells the story of a 25-year-old man living in modern Russia who finds himself mysteriously transported to a summer camp somewhere in the former Soviet Union.\n\nThis novel is very good. The story was amazing. In game there are 13 possible endings. Some endings are lovely with some romance others are sad, mystical and scary. The music fits the mood, so the atmosphere in game is great. The background pictures are very beautiful, but character pictures wasn't that great. The main character will see many naked girls, kiss them and will have sex, but you will only see the black screen. Damn, lucky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. My life sucks. By the way the doctor in infirmary is so hot. The gameplay is simple. I like that when you are replaying game, the skipping function only skips the parts you played, but you can't skip parts that you play first time. Also when you are choosing different paths the text color is different too, so you know which paths you have already chose and which not. In overall this game made me feel many different emotions. This game is great and if you are fan of visual novels and love interesting stories when you should definitely try this game.

reviewText:
From the beginning, this game felt as if it had been written for people like me. The protagonist represented almost everything I felt about my life to this date. He is man with no self-identifiable talents, skills, or ambitions. He is an adult who can’t find his place in the world and passes his life in front of a computer screen. It was almost overwhelming to read my life described by a complete stranger, yet somewhat comforting at the same time.

The story is set up with a dream sequence followed by an internal monologue which succeeds in placing you in the mind of the protagonist.  It is abruptly after this that some unusual circumstances place the protagonist in a situation where he is completely removed from his daily routine. After falling asleep on a bus in the city, in winter, he wakes up in an unfamiliar location in the summer. He finds himself at entrance to a mysterious soviet camp, populated mainly by girls. It is ultimately up to him, with the assistance of the player, to discover how and why these events came to pass, while forging relationships with the campers along the way.

The music and scenery are wonderful and achieve the correct mood for each scene. Knowing very little about Russia I found the locations to be unique and interesting especially compared to the Japanese games I'm accustomed to. The character designs, which are modelled after anime style, displayed a lot of effort and talent from the designers.  The usual character archetypes are present allowing the player to experience a variety of different personalities among the campers. Additionally the player is provided with a reasonable amount of choices throughout the story, which is something I have found lacking from many visual novels. Multiple story paths and steam achievements add further replay value to the game, and I will endeavour to experience the entire story over multiple play throughs. The only downfall I can find is some issues with spelling and translation, but these do not hinder the story and could be fixed with a small patch.

Everlasting Summer is a masterpiece and I am thankful that the team behind it gave us an English release. I was even more thankful that it was release for free. Given the option I would have happily paid for a game of this quality.

reviewText: Well, I started to play this out of a whim ... and was sort of surprised. I can´t say that I didn´t like the girls Endings, but they where ... well,  sort of okayish at best. As a Horror-fan I definetely liked the Sasha/Miku Route. But Yulyas route ... well, that one has been in full cry. I guess it´s almost safe to say, that we´ve got one of the games here, which becomes better the older YOU are when you´re playing it. Perhaps its just a personal thing - I don´t really know, nor do I actually care - but, I suppose the older you are, the more you have actually experienced in your life, the more you´ll be able to understand what the protagonist is thinking about, what is bothering him. On the other hand - it actually manages it, to give you this slight nostalgic feeling. Which is interesting in a certain way .... I grew up in western Germany, in the late 1980s I was a little bit younger than Semyon. I should not really be able to compare my expiriences to the life of an adolescent in the late years of the sovient union. It might be a side effect of this game, a wanted thing - or whatever you prefer to call it ... but darn, I can relate. It sort of feels familiar. Okay, it wasn´t called Pioneers - we had boy scouts, like in the states. But ♥♥♥♥, some memories surely came back. It actually leads me to some sort of conclusion, I´ve had heard some while ago: It doesn´t matter where you live, where you´ve grown up - the basic hopes, wishes and desires remain the same - anywhere. So - I´d like to tip my hat to the developers, for granting us an interesting experience here and I hope this won´t be that last game we see from you.

reviewText:
This is an Visual Novel so if you're not interesting in spending hours on reading dialogue and the thoughts of the main character then this is not a game for you.
After having read all of the endings that this VN has to offer I can say that this is an amazing one.

TL:DR Just play it it's worth your time, it got great art, music and an really interesting storyline.

Pros:
Not too short and not too long, keeps the reader interested and the different routes isn't that similar to eachother.
Outstanding soundtrack
The main character is actually interesting.
Detailed and beautiful BG and CG with an unique artstyle
Choices aren't too few but neither too many, an overall interesting and fun flowchart.
It's made by RussiansThe graphics suffers from having many different artstyles and can seem inconsistent. This can be seen as both a Pro and Con. I personally enjoyed this aspect of the VN.
There isn't many cons but it does exist a few minor problems.
Cons
The sprites does look quite bland and isn't close to as good looking as the rest of the art.
The english translation suffers from quite many spelling misstakes and probably grammar misstakes aswell.
(I do not have english as my 1st language so I'm not the best one to judge that.)
It can sometimes lag because of the Ren'py engine, especially while fast forwarding.
If you are russian or atleast know russian you will probably get a better experience from reading this.
The steam achievements doesn't unlock correctly. Ths doesn't really affect the VN but it can be annoying for people who wants all of the achievements.

Graphics 7/10
I have alot of mixed feelings when it comes to the graphics. One part of me wants to say that it's a masterpiece another wants to think it's mediocre and bland. Both of them are though correct. The backgrounds are really beautiful, great colouring, shading and attention to detail. The main menu looks great and is unique. The CG wich is only meant to be seen in specific scenes looks really unique and has this more sketchy and abstract artstyle, they don't have that much detail but the colours and composition just makes it look amazing. The one thing that makes me give the graphics a 7 and not a 9 or even a 10 is the sprites of the characters. They are the things you will see most of the time and they just look uninteresting and just generally mediocre and nothing special. It still looks good but seeing how great the CG and BG is then it's sad that the sprites drag them down.

Sound and effects 9/10
The sound effects is great. They manage to use them at the correct time to set an great atmosphere. It really does enhance the experience alot. One example is that they use the sound of grasshoppers alot to make a more unsettling feeling or make the characters just feel annoyance, probably inspired by Higurashi.

Soundtrack 10/10
The music is just perfect. The first time I opened up this VN I got stuck on the main menu just listening to the main menu theme. The soundtrack is devided into two parts, the bright side and the dark side. The differents parts is made by different people. They truly create diversity in soundtrack with more classical music, rock and some more modern music. It really complements the story and helps create the correct atmosphere and emotions. I don't think I will ever get tired of listening to this soundtrack.

Characters 8/10
The characters is mainly your normal harem clichés. The caring and loving one is there, the tsundere one and ofcourse the mischievous loli is there aswell. But even if you have seen similar characters elsewhere they all feel new and interesting. All of them is really well-written and makes you want to come back to the VN to read all of their routes. Their graphical design is really nice and fresh, they really isn't your typical japanese manga characters.

Story 10/10
The story is the main attraction and luckily it's also the best part (maybe beaten by the soundtrack). It's well-written and feels unique and fresh. All of the routes is interesting, the characters and events is perfectly made. The story might seem like your normal slice-of-life VN but if you see past of that skin you'll see a more philosophical and surreal story. Putting this VN in a genre can be hard, is it a slice-of-life, a horror, maybe even a sci-fi? The routes are ineresting and worthwhile alone but to truly appreciate this story you need to read all of them and look at the whole picture. At all of the metaphors it uses and the philosophical meaning behind it. The VN uses alot of references to other games, animes etc. so to be able to enjoy it to the fullest you need to have some knowledge about that. I think I personally have missed out on alot of inside-jokes and references since I'm not russian or can read russian. So If you can read russian I would recommend to read the russian version instead of the english translation.

Overall experience  10/10
Overall this is an amazing visual novel and it's one of the best I have read, and I have read quite a few. It is by far the best VN you will find on steam and it even has the perk of being free. I would recommend this to anyone even if you aren't used to VNs or other things this might refer to. You will be able to enjoy it, maybe not to the fullest but it will still be an great experience.
This is an eroge so there will be sexscenes, though you need to download the hentai patch from their website.
Hentai patch can be found here [everlastingsummer.su]
Though I do not think the eroge scenes really are needed, they are all very short and some of them feel very out of place.
If you decide to read this VN wich I think you should then I can promise that you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
Niesamowita. Wspaniała. Cudowna.
Incredible. Great. Wonderful.
Невероятно. Отлично. Замечательно.
10/10

This game transfered me to my childhood. It brought back a lot of my memories. Summer camps, first love, heart dilemmas, hard decisions (in young person opinion).
Everlasting Summer gives such feelings in a great way, especially that i was teenager in 80s :)
Stories told in the game are very interesting. There are plenty endings depending on our choices during the game. Some of them are really surprising.
Also music is worth mentioning which helps to build the atmosphere in this production. Few melodies will stay in my head for a longer time. Can't say anything bad about graphics. The pictures are very nicely drawn.
Furthermore, the game shows that our decisions have consequences in the future. They can affect the fate of others, even in a tragic way, so we should think twice before saying/doing anything. Much depends on the nature of the other person, but we are able to hurt anybody.
I highly recommend this game, especially to the older generation of players.

Mnie ta gra przeniosła w czasie do moich lat młodości. Obudziła wiele wspomnień. Letnie obozy, pierwsze miłości, rozterki sercowe, trudne decyzje (jak na tamten wiek).
Gra niesamowicie oddaje ten klimat, tym bardziej, że nastolatkiem byłem właśnie w latach 80-tych :)
Opowiedziane w grze historie są bardzo interesujące. Zależnie od naszych wyborów mamy różne zakończenia gry. Niektóre z nich są bardzo zaskakujące.
Na wyróżnienie zasługuje również muzyka, która tworzy bardzo fajny klimat. Kilka melodii bardzo zapadło mi w pamięć. Podobnie grafika, która jest bardzo ładnie narysowana.
Gra pokazuje ponadto, że nasze decyzje mają konsekwencje w przyszłości. Mogą one wpłynąć na los innych osób, nawet w tragiczny sposób. Nasze postępowanie nie jest bez znaczenia, dlatego czasem trzeba się zastanowić, zanim coś zrobimy lub powiemy. Wiele zależy od charakteru drugiej osoby, ale skrzywdzić można każdego.
Serdecznie polecam tą grę, szczególnie starszemu pokoleniu graczy.

reviewText:
Some don't like this game because there's not much choice.

Facts are there isn't a lot of choiceand in some conversations I would've said different things than what the player character would have said.

Some don't like this game because boobs/anime/it's an eroge/it's a VN/it's a dating sim.

Honestly, I've never been one to like dating sims (look at my most played games) or anime, or any of the things above. I never hated them but never really thought it was for me.

Anyways this game kinda changed that. Sure there's women with large breasts and sex if you add the hentai patch. However the focus is on the characters and the relatively mature themes of what to do with life, the nature of existence, and the excellent plot, and most importantly, the effects of one's actions on others. The writing apart from the funky translation is good, but if you've talked to actual russian girls they tend to say things the same way so there's a degree of veracity to it.

This ties in well with the nice soundtrack and excellent background art.

Also of note is that each ending really has a different message and life lesson. Is it a little corny? sure, but at the same time it feels like it was a good use of my time and made me really feel. Not only one emotion, but probably every ending will bring a different range of emotions.

Then once you've finished all the basic girl endings, the game takes that and throws it out the window. It goes to almost Tarkovsky levels of insanity and mind/reality bending and will make you super confused. Think through it for an hour, put the pieces together and you'll realise the developers were either blackout drunk or genius when they wrote the overarching story. Then, you truly have experienced this game.

Overall, if I was to describe this game in 3 words? Feels, thoughts, experience.

reviewText:
My Neverending Summer
First of all this is my first virtual novel ever played so keep that in mind while reading :)
I came across this game because I'd like to play something romantic. I saw the Pictures on
steam and the trailer witch are pretty nice so i taught lets give it a shot, its free anyway!
Although this is not that kind of game that i usually play. ( no guns! ) Reading from the steam page the only thing yure doing in this game is reading
with ongoing mouse klicking. Yeha right, i thaught i might dump it from my Hardrive
if it gets boring right away! After installing it i jumped right into it, on the fist half of my very first walkthrough
i got a bit bord but on the second half i just got hit from a emotion-sledgehammer. (ok, maybe i am exaggerateing but i'd like the phrase) To summ things up I really enjoyd it!

Comming to the main part of  my Review, The game is only available in english and russian,
translations are made by the comunity so upcomming translation mods might not be 100%
Gramatical right. But reading is not the only thing for you to enjoy, the music in this game is
BREATHTAKING! I absolutely adore it ! It takes the atmosphaere of this game to the next lvl
making me shiver serval times. The background  sounds are also great, fitting the current location and Situiation very well. Speaking of background, the locations are beautiful drawn so it never
gets old watching them once in a while. However characters in this game look a litte bit
odd, not badly drawn but the artstlye is some kind of a crossover between a japanese dog and an Russian one. Don't get me wrong i like it, an more japanese looking one won't fit
the interesting Sovjet Setting. Moveing on to the story wich is the Backbone of this
game so leave it, if it isn't interesting to you. Lucky this is pretty hard due to a
wellthaught and  fascinating story. Providing a lot of different genre typs on each
13 endings/Paths: romance, adventure, mystery, drama and even Horror. Sadly only half
of them are uniqe and you need to play the story from the beginning to do other
choices and get another endig. Sometimes you can save before the ending
and collect the other one if you choose different. All in all i recomend to achieve
them completely so you get the wahole story together. After 6 hours of trying and
failing i allowed myself the rudeness to look up all remainig endings on YT.
Admittedly it would be boring it its so easy to get all endings. Finally
you can pick up lots of new storys on the Steam Workshop if youre
hungry for more, watchout though most of them are only in russian
available. If you are a fan like i am you can support the developer
by buying the ingame music on itunes and google play.
To end this review ladys and Gentleman just play it by yourself
its absultely worth your time and free, i strongly recommend to
pick it up!

PS: DISCARD THAT NIFE LENA!!!!

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer is a fantastic entry in the (recently) busy visual novels scene on Steam. The Russian Ilchan community-built effort delivers a satisfyingly deep and twisting set of story lines around a metaphysical setting in a 1980s Soviet Pioneer camp.

The nostalgic setting, which hit one close to home for me as I spent my youth in the USSR, is complimented by genuinely interesting plots and sub-plots that can satisfy and, sometimes, shock you, with a set of serviceable sound effects and musical vignettes, manga-inspired characters and a semi-realistic background art style. Without revealing anything of the key plot elements, I strongly recommend exploring ALL the available routes to completion and wrap up the story with the Harem End.

Highly recommended and it is, after all, free! 5/5

reviewText: I am not into anime, or visual novels for that matter, so I did not have any expectations going in. Everlasting Summer really surprised me. It certainly left its mark.\n\nIf you enjoy reading and thinking, you should give this one a try (it is free, afterall). But the content is definitely intended for a mature audience (and I do not mean adult content).

reviewText:
TL;DR A must have FREE game. Go download this unforgettable experience right flippin' now. You will not regret it. Everything is so great about this if you have the time to dwell deeper in to the story and not just stop after one playthrough. It will just leave you empty. Trust me! The game is worth every hour you play it.

Everlasting Summer - an unforgettable experience rather than your regular visual novelI never thought a game, or rather a novel, could actually give me such strong emotional reactions over the stuff that happens in it. Everlasting Summer, on the other hand, fixed it.

Everlasting Summer tells a story about a male, Semyon, who gets on a bus and falls asleep. Rather than waking up in the bus or the bus station he wakes up in a pioneer camp not knowing how he got there and why he is there. From this point the story takes a huge leap to more and more absurd things to happen.

I'm not really a heavy reader. I don't read much. But for some reason Everlasting Summer kept me interested, kept me enetertained, kept me wanting to see more. There hasn't been a story that could make me lose my sleep just to see what's next. There hasn't been a story that actually made me focus on it without noticing my surroundings. There hasn't been a story that could actually get heavy emotions out of me.

The visuals, the writing, the soundtrack. Without these three key elements the story wouldn't have been so powerful. All these elements merged into a one epic and unforgettable experience I won't forget in a long time. Everything worked and behaved so well between each other creating even a physical feel at times. Now, I won't spoil anything about the game but there are parts, especially in your first playthrough, which will, or at least I hope, make you feel just like the characters in the story feel at the particular moment. It may be a little bit of cheating adding audio-visual elements in to a written story but because Everlasting Summer is such an absurd tale having you rush through different kinds of emotions you really need to have something to strenghten the emotions, in good and bad.

Now for the part which is about the story or the theme of the game. Show the spoiler in order to view it. I won't spoil the actual plot but I will be explaining the basic elements in each storyline, which may or may not affect your first playthrough experiance.

Everlasting summer isn't just your typical tale about going to a summer camp, or a pioneer camp in this case, finding a girl and getting it on with her. Oh no, not even close to being one! Or maybe I'm just praising this a little bit too much because the main storylines are about getting the girl you want which will affect the rest of your life. In a good way or a bad way depending on which enging you got. But that's what makes playing the main storylines interesting, getting a glimpse of the absurd happenings in the camp and after the camp, each time revealing something new about the story and Semyon's life.

The fun doesn't stop there though, quite the opposite actually. After unlocking all the good endings with all the girls in the camp and your own good ending you are now able to complete (???) and Harem ending, which will explain the plot furthermore. These endings will give you more answers. These ending will give out the plot and theme of the game. They construct the story all over again and make you think more deeply about the story rather than just seeing it as a dating simulator (although it's pretty obvious to see everything is not right in the camp. These endings just give you more answers, as I said above).

Now for my own thought about the story and theme. Spoilers (again)!

I'm not really 100% sure what the theme of the game was but the theme I got out of this game was finding yourself, knowing what means being you, what you personally think you need in your own life. The secret (???) ending will give you this idea pretty clearly. And the free DLC (which can be located from Options and scrolling down to Mods) will give you even more answers and supporting ideas over this theme. The game is about understanding your life, making lifetime decisions, deciding what makes you... YOU! A really pwerful motivational theme over a wonderfully attractive game visual and audio wise.

After completing the main storylines you will be left with unanswered questions (which I talked about behind those spoilers) but there are a couple of more secret storylines to enlighten you about the whole story. As I said, it's more than just a dating simulator. It much more deeper than that. And the (???) ending, Harem ending and a free DLC ending, which can be located from the Options menu scrolling down to the bottom in the Mod section called 'Pioneer's Day', will give you all the answers you need regarding to the story. I strongly recommend playing the DLC after getting all the storyline achievements.

And for all the perverts out there, yes, I tried out the Hentai-patch which, surprisingly, didn't ruin the game. It doesn't really add anything new to the table other than some boobs and a couple of sex scenes but if you truly are playing this game for the story you will not find the scenes sexually appealing in any way.

Everlasting Summer was one of the very few Visual Novels I've played but I still could say Everlasting Summer will end up as one of my favourite games of all time for years to come. Maybe even to the day I die.

reviewText:
This game. My God, this game.
Everlasting Summer is exactly what you would expect from a visual novel - a game that basically plays itself and let's you make a few (quite important) choices, depending on which your story progresses and eventually gets you to one of the 13 endings the game has to offer. Yep, 13. Quite impressive, right? If you're a fan of visual novels, what you've already read has probably got you hooked, but this game is something way more than just a visual novel.
First of all, this game is free. No micro transactions, no expensive DLC that actually holds 50% of the story. Absolutely free. It's even available on mobile devices, again, for free.
I'm not a huge fan of visual novels. I have barely even played any of the Telltale games, and I did approach Everlasting Summer with a bit of skepticism, considering the fact it was a FREE visual novel. But after just a couple of minutes in the game, I was hooked, I just could not get off, I could not stop playing. This game is an absolute masterpiece. Every dialogue, every scene, every possible outcome of the story is perfected. The story, in general, is amazing, It is original, fun, surprising and involves some beautiful plot twists at times. The atmosphere of the game is stunningly good, the music is always on point and so well made that it gave me the chills every other minute while playing the game and I still can't shake it off. I've been playing the game for 2 days and I've got 2 of the possible endings unlocked, but I look forward to getting each and every secret of that game unveiled, because it's definitely worth the time.
There is a reason this game is free - everyone should play it at some point of their life. Go now, Sovyonok awaits your arrival.

reviewText:
NOTE Just 9 minutes before I submitted this review, Steam forced all adult content to be removed. This is around 25 images. I am very sad. This irritates me. The complete version is not this, so this game is incomplete. Still highly reccomend, but flips sake.... Don't worry about missing actual content though I suppose, just that the screen is black ^_^

Okay, so this review isn't really structured, nor is it perfect, and nor does it have a valid conclusion, but it does tell you how I feel about this amazing game, and how I'd recommend it to everyone in a heartbeat. It may contain slight spoilers, but nothing that will reveal anything to a new player, or spoil anything for a current player. I finished this game in a single weekend to 100% completion in 23.9 hours game time. I may never have completed this visual novel, had I not set myself a target to beat it in under 24 hours, in a single weekend, and I just about managed it at 4:50 am. The reason for perhaps not finishing is how much I felt it was all nonsense, and clutching at straws, but that was never the case, so I urge you to play it all. So I started off with Everlasting Summer because I was tired of losing in every other game I was playing. I was feeling down, and remebered how happy other visual novels have always made me feel in the past. I was a bit unsure to start it, as the art style didn't appeal to me to initially, and the music seemed boring. Oh I was very wrong. Sure, the pictures in the gallery are all drawn in different styles by different people, but that doesn't mean they are bad pieces. They each provide multiple views, and allow you to see each character more realistically, which is a nice touch. The music is amazing. Tracks like 410, Blow with the Fires, Mystery Girl, Forest Maiden, Orchid, Trespassing and Pile give a nice feel of both sadness, happiness and just awe, fitting in appropriately with whats happening in the story, and there are also comical tracks which often accompany our favourite little USSR shirted 14 year old. The characters grow upon you and everything is great.... untill you finish the first route after around 5-6 hours of playing, and are left shocked, disheartened, and almost definitly confused.
Chances are, you flunked it hard. (The point scoring method used in this game is difficult, and unless you're reasonably smart, or lucky, or both,) you'll end up with a Seymon end. Now this isn't at all bad, but a certain pioneer will tell you some things, that will make you sad about some of the girls, and care less about what happens. You'll be all confused, but intrigued and go on to play the game, in attempt to actually get somewhere. (You will, I promise.) I flunked again, and got the other Seymon end, and then on my 4th runthrough, I achieved my first girl route. This left me confused.... I had beaten the first challenge the game had to offer, I had reduced the contents of my scrotum, and yet nothing made much sense. THIS IS WHERE I THINK MANY PEOPLE GIVE UP. reviewText:
My first ever game review here; and I will explain shortly why this is the case.

I normally don't bother writing reviews for anything because when I write a review, it is usually serious and well thought-out, and that takes time. A lot of time.

Now why did I bother to write a review this time, for this Free-To-Play (eroge?) game no less? Because the contents of this game totally (and very surprisingly) entertained and amused me for the past few hours I played it from start to finish without so much as a pause.

Now, I don't play eroge games often. In fact, I never played one, until Everlasting Summer that is. I simply played this game because, well, it's free; but also because the other reviews heavily favours its storytelling over the visual aspect of the game. Curiosity got the better of me, so I thought, Why not? First time for everything
recommended: I will tell you readers right now

During my first two hours

reviewText:
It's probably one of the best (if not the best ) self-motivation experiences i've ever had.
Main character, ♥♥♥♥♥/Semyon, is a typical  nerd dota player and weaboo  man of XXI postindustrial century who realized his life is nothing but empty bottle and now wants serious changes in his life (yeah,all of us living like him i'm sure). However, how the changes supposed to happen on its own if you’re just netsurfing whole days/months/years? Maybe it’s time for some changes? Yeah, time for shaking your ♥♥♥ and moving on!
It's highly recommended to play this only once and without restarts  (for example,poker play)  to see your true ending that depends only on YOUR decisions. Just remember one thing: there is no ideal ending, think of it as a life-test and make your point. Then you can observe another endings and make interesting conclusion about yourself and maybe your own life. I’ve spent only one night with this masterpiece. This one is very refreshing for your head and makes you think deeper, even if you deal with something trivial during your lifetime,something you didn’t notice before.
Indeed,10 pioneer badges of 10.
P.S.  Got a bad ending with Alice and i’m pretty satisfied with results :)
P.P.S.  18+ hentai content included :О

reviewText:
First, this is not what you can call a date sim. Second, it has little to do with Soviet nostalgia, quite the opposite, actually.
In its core it is a mystical story of self-discovery, filled with existential thoughts and occasional melancholy. Despite that the game manages to take the player through all kinds of emotions, blending various genres, including romance, comedy and even horror.
The story is long and quite slow-paced, while the various endings of the game surprisingly form into one big metastory with subsequent metaendings which must be experienced in their entirety in order to truly appreciate everything the game has to offer.
Beautiful music and gorgeous backgrounds, story log and fast forward options, gallery with unlockables and workshop with mods.
In short, this game is better than the majority of paid visual novels on Steam, so why aren't you playing it yet?

reviewText:
I will make a more serious review instead of a more funny one like my others, because i think this game/visual novel is just one of the best out there.

Well... this game/visual novel, is something i download just to try it, and i was just mind blown when it turned out to be one of the best games i ever played, in steam it says i only have 6 hours, but i also play a lot in offline mode, so in truth i have around 15 to 20 hours.
I´m not into reading, i just don't like it, but i think that is normal for people my age (17 years old), i never liked to read at school, i never read a book completely, the few times i tryed i quited after 10 minutes.
So less about me and more about the game, this game is amazing, it has a story who can hook you for hours, you have to make decisions and that changes how the story goes, which for me its something every game with a story should have, plus it has a very gorgeous design and image and in the top of that, one of the most beautifull soundtracks ever.
This game/visual novel, will mess with your feelings, you will be sad,happy,confused, and will leave you thinking about life for hours after you stopped playing it.

To finish i could give you a resume about the story but i would just be spoiling it for you, so follow my advice try it and you won't regret it, i certainly didn't and i think this game/visual novel open a whole new world for me and i just love the way the game messes with my emotions.

So to this game i give a 10 out of 10.

P.S - Sorry for my english, im portuguese, and thank you for reading my review :)

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer is one of the more unusual romantic visual novels I've play, with a surprisingly deep and immersive plot and enjoyable characters. There are a number of flaws, but most of them are superficial and don't diminish the enjoyability of the game to any significant extreme.

The Plot:
The plot is fantastic. For a casual romantic-visual novel player, the surface layer of the game should more than be enjoyable, with four major romantic routes and definitive happy endings. However, as you delve farther into the story of Sovionok and Everlasting Summer, the plot starts twisting and reveals rather bizarre undertones. There are three additional paths beyond the four basic love interests, one of which is only reachable having traversed the other six and getting fully immersed into the story. This final path ties the story together and really draws the game to a satisfying conclusion.

The Main Character:
Semyon, the protagonist, is honestly one of the worst elements of this game. For introverts and shut-ins, he is first portrayed as a very relatable character, and is subject to getting drawn into this bizarre world by chance. However, it doesn't take long before you're likely pulling out your hair at how idiotic he regularly is. He regularly gets lost on strange mental tangents and runs circles repeatedly over subjects that should easily be dropped. While he fortunately realizes the emotions of his female counterparts faster than your average anime protagonist, he tends to get infuriatingly confused with his own emotions. However, this is probably the only major gripe I have with this game.

The Rest of the Cast:
Each character is their own unique and special snowflake, resulting in a small but colorful cast. Some of the characters come off as rather two dimensional, but this is typically subverted as the story progresses. All of your favorite romance tropes are in full effect here - the tsundere, the vanilla sweetheart, the wallflower - fortunately, again, they aren't typically confined to their roles. Probably one of the stronger points of the game would be character development and interactions; admittedly it would be a poor visual novel otherwise.

The Art:
The art can be... peculiar. A lot of it is recycled and reused, to mixed effect. In addition, the artist's seemed to be incapable of agreeing on certain details, most notably Olga's color scheme. However for the most part the art is of acceptable quality and is at it's best at the most important times, namely the endings and emotional high points.

The Music:
Not much to note here. I don't see myself downloading an OST or coming back to listen to it specifically, but the music is of good enough quality and certainly most excellently used.

The Replay:
This game has a high, almost mandatory replay value. There are up to seven individual paths you can go down, with all but one having two endings. As previously mentioned, the final path can only be unlocked after you have completed all other paths. As far as replaying through the game goes, you will be appreciative of the fast-forward button. Many events are fully or heavily independant of which route you're going down, and being given a tour of the camp thirteen seperate times is not something I want to sit through in full.

The Notes:
Three final points come to mind. Firstmost: yes, this game was originally written in Russian. While the translation is commendable, the spelling isn't perfect and the grammar sometimes bears tinges of a speaker who knows English as a second language. Unless you are an insufferable grammar Nazi, this should be mildly distracting at it's worst. Secondly: If you are looking for a specific ending (which is likely), I would advise looking up a guide. Many, if not most, endings are near-impossible to get without knowing exactly which decisions to make. For example, the four main character's good or bad endings are decided on a points-based system: at least six points will put you on that character's path, and at least nine points will net you the good end. Alisa has exactly nine points total. In addition, Miku's path is only acchievable after certain conditions are met and you must make the exact right decisions to trigger it. Not a huge detriment, just a warning. Finally, this game was originally advertised as an adult-rated game, but as of a patch a few days ago as-of me writing this, the adult content has been removed. This doesn't really harm the story much, but it's also not particularly difficult to mod the adult content back in. Take it as you will.

In conclusion, this game has it's faults, but it is definitely one of the better visual novels available, and I highly recommend playing it. It's free, what do you have to lose? Time? If you've gotten this far through my review, you obviously have free time. Go play it.

reviewText:
I don't write reviews often, but i just had to with this game. Everlasting Summer was recently translated to English and in my opinion is very overlooked and underrated, more people definitely need to find this amazing gem of a visual novel.

This was my first time playing a visual novel and i probably won't ever forget it, the Story is absolutely amazing and very interesting at that with a total of 13 endings and different choices and routes to take (i highly recommend getting all endings to get the whole story of the game). You can easily find spoiler free Guides or Walkthroughs on how to get certain endings if you want, which is what i ended up doing. You can automatically fast forward through all the scenes which you've already seen and the game will automatically stop when it reaches words or scenes you haven't read or seen.

The music in Everlasting Summer is fantastic and probably one of the best parts of the game, trust me, it will get stuck in your head for a while.

The art was overall pretty good, although certain scenes were drawn and had slight quirks, it can be easily overlooked and actually adds a certain charm to it and you get used to it, the background CGs more than make up for it.

On average the game should take about 15-20 hours to get all endings and the game is free + it also has free DLC! The game is about 800 MB and is definitely worth installing and trying out.

Steam however has the game censored, but you can go to the official website of Everlasting Summer here[everlastingsummer.su] and get a simple drag & drop patch to restore the censored scenes if you wish.

TL;DR Amazing free visual novel with lots of endings, fantastic music, great CGs and an amazing story. Give it a try!

reviewText:
Every story has its beginning and its end.
Every story has its canvas, synopsis, contents, key moments, prologue and epilogue.
And there is no book that re-reading it would not reveal new details that you hadn't noticed before.
But every book has a last page. And after turning it over, we put the book on the shelf.
Just to open a new one tomorrow...
I can't express how much i love Everlasting Summer. When i'm looking for a visual novel, i'm mostly interested in it's story, like reading a good book. And this one is indeed became one of my favourites...

Okay, i'll start with the cons, let's get this over with, there is a really few.
The drawings at some places are interesting, and not in a good way. It's not that bad, but characters can totally end up differently in one or two scenes.

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic game! The writing is rough but its charm will win you over before you even realize it. So, so many different endings each satisfying and worth pursuing. I also like the overall story here, it's a bit of a deconstruction of the typical Visual Novel. We see our protagonist in a bad state (Yes, a typical anime shut-in) but believe me you begin rooting for our character (and its worth noting that in all my experiences with novels there's only been a few times where I agreed completely with every action of the hero- and this is one of them. In other words its no Sakura Spirit haha). But by the end there is a serious change that's honestly inspiring.

For a free, a FREE ♥♥♥♥ing game, I was completely blown away by the quality. Now, don't set your expectations too high. A large factor of my enjoyment of this game is because I went in with rock bottom expectations but if you're looking for a review to just win you over enough- play it. It has a lot of heavy russian culture and names, the pacing is rough, I can see a few endings being completely horrendous for a first playthrough (i.e. Lela bad end and any of the non-girl endings). And I'd say if the charm of nostalgia, summer camps, cute girls, and living life to the fullest doesn't win you over you might have some problems with the rough writing as well- it's not bad at all but there were one or two moments.

Overall, for having rock bottom expectations: I was completely blown away. But if you read this then it's an above average visual novel with a very inspiring dynamic main character, several endings that range from sweet- to brutal- to loving- to sci fi wonders, and a certain charm that drew me in completely. So without my rock bottom expectations being blown away I'd honestly give it a high recommendation (very high for fans of VN's)- I don't do that score ♥♥♥♥

(As of this time I have 7 hours and can see myself clocking in 10 hours at 100% completetion to those worried about length. The normal campaign with one ending will take 5-6 hours)

reviewText:
One of the biggest suprises of 2014 and imo one of the best (indie)game titles of the year. This one is definitely going on my personal favorites list. Gameplay-wise it's good, nothing too bad but also nothing too spectecular. Story-wise however that's a whole another thing. Each of the 13 stories start off slow but develop into an incredible and emotional story. I would even dare to say that story-wise this game is up there a long with the bioshock-series and telltale games like TWD en TWAU.

Slightly spoiler but:
1st - the Miku-route/ending is absolutely mind blowing. It's a legit 2 hour horror movie (horror movie junkies will understand what I mean)

2nd - you should definitely try to get the Yulia-route/ending, it will explain the whole story and will leave you with a satisfied feeling (this route is also a 2 hour special, just as the Miku-route/ending)
(best played as very last storyline after you've done all the other storylines)

3rd - make sure that you save before making the choice of going further or going back in the Yulia-route/ending, because you gonna want to play the harem-ending right after the Yulia-ending for further explanation of the game and this story

4th - if you're a completionist like me and want to get the whole photoalbum completed, make sure to save before you make a decision with who you want to wake up with during the Yulia-route/ending


I would conclude with saying that I would like to thank the creators of this game for giving me and the fellow gamers who downloaded this game such an incredible experience. The fact that it's free to play suprises me because I would be happily paying 10-20 bucks for this game, considering the amount of gameplay and story we get.

Verdict 10/10

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer is a well written Visual Novel.  I am new to this genre, however I find the multiple choice branches to several alternate story lines and  interesting endings make it a cut above most VN's.  It has existentialist aspects, bringing to my mind Luigi Pirandello's {1934 Nobel Laureate} play “Six Characters in Search of an Author”.

The “hidden” stories and screens in the alternate story lines add a lot to the enjoyment of the game.  I have found the game to be quite interesting and, as a ”Free To Play”, it's hard to beat the price.

As the protagonist, you are a 21st Century middle-age man drawn into a strangely inter-time-dimensional mystery as a generally mediocre {fill in choice for field of endeavor; guitarist, scholar, programmer, on-line consultant, interpersonal relations, etc.} failure.  After boarding a bus during a snowy Winter evening in a large Russian city, you fall asleep and awaken to find yourself in an abandoned bus at the gate to some sort of camp bearing the name “Sovyonok”.  And there's a slight catch; it's a bright Summer day and you still are wearing your winter attire and heavy boots!

There you are met by a pretty young girl who apparently thinks there's nothing strange about you?!  You learn that this is a late Soviet era Pioneer Camp for youths at some indeterminate remote location.  The beautiful young Camp Director has been expecting you and, due to lack of space, she's your roomie!  But that is not enough “strange”.  Before long you have a chance to look in a mirror and see a teenager!!  And so it goes.

WHAT is going on?  Can you figure out how this happened and get back to your “present”?  Do you WANT to get back or should you try to stay here?

During my first pass through this VN, I found the story to be interesting but could not figure out how to direct the story line to a desirable ending.  Result?  Protagonist “Bad Ending”!  There are many {have not counted} choices which may provide potential turning points.  There are at least 5 potential love Interests and a missing fellow Pioneer {I almost typed “prisoner”}.

In bewilderment, I turned to the Community Guides for, what else, guidance.  While, with a large number of attempts, I might eventually have been able to figure them out, the guides are saving what probably would have been months of effort.  The reward has been significantly differing sets of story lines as the {now} young man explores relationships with the girls of Sovyonok. Will there be happy times or more failures and disappointments for the protagonist?

Music:  Usually when I play a game, the BGM is turned down to a bare minimum so it won't disturb me.  As I played Everlasting Summer, I kept finding myself turning the sound level up so I could enjoy the MUSIC.  The Music selections are very well done.  The BGM changes with the scenes and the characters.  It serves to enhance the mood appropriately as one progresses through this excellent VN.  I particularly liked the guitar riffs. I had to turn BGM up to maximum for those.

Everlasting Summer presents extras including Background screens, Character screens, Sprite screens and a long list of Music selections.  There are about 100 Save slots.  While that seems to be a lot, due to the many story lines, I ran out of room and had to save over some early saves.

Particularly if you have an interest in visual novels, you should play Everlasting Summer

Expecting to control a character in the traditional way is misguided, because that is not how the game is played. A visual novel is just that, a novel that tells a story through narration (traditionally, and as is in Everlasting Summer, through text) and a simple use of pictures and character images. reviewText:
Product received for free

It is a really good game and it is very emotional. Being a game of choice, there are some REALLY happy choices that can be mad, as well as some REALLY depressing ones, but also a fair deal of neutral ones too.

I do not really know if I would classify it as a positive or a negative but the emotional reactions I had to it were extremely strong. And one of the things I tend to pride myself on in life is a general stoic attitude, so these emotions were intense for me. (It being a 'positive' because it did what it was probably intended to do... and that was to make me extremely depressed, the negative).

All in all, though, even with that, I would still say that it was a good game, I enjoyed playing it, and am trying to get others interested in it.

reviewText:
This is the first time I've ever wrote such a long review for anything.

For what it's worth, Everlasting Summer is a compelling visual novel that takes branching storylines to a different level. Granted, I did notice a ton of translation errors as wel as typos, but that didnt stop me any from enjoying the storyline either way. Now allow me to explain why in this handy list.

1: Main character

The protagonist, Semyon, Is kind of relatable in a way to many people. He starts the story off as some average joe without any distinct characteristics. However, each time you play (and replay), you find that he adapts based on the events that happen to him in each playthrough. And, trust me, if you truly wish to get a full understanding of who Semyon truly is and what his role is in this tale, you'll play it more than once.

2: Other Characters

No tale can be made with just one character (at least none that I've payed attention to). Thankfully, Soviet Games added characters who were not only engaging but quirky (different to each other, if you will). You have Slavya, the kindhearted epitome of the ideal pioneer, Lena, the quiet but mysterious girl who may be hiding more than she lets on, Alisa, the hardcore vixen with a softcore heart, Miku, the talkative Russian/Japanese, and Ulyana, the little sister" who always ends up causing mayhem somehow.

And let's not forget about side characters who dive the story further. Characters ranging from Olga Dmitrievna
date: the often strict but sometimes fair camp leader
recommended:
to the mysterious Pioneer who always seems to pop in and out from time to time.

3: Storyline.

Soviet Games outdid themselves when they wrote the storylines for this game. Not only did the center the game entirely around the choices you made but it also allowed for very compelling reading. Each branch of the story can send the reader into a wave of emotions any any moment. One minute you're laughing at the antics of one of the pioneers
hoursPlayed: the next moment could send you into a wave of sorrow at how things turned out. Whether it be comedy or romance
voteText:
Everlasting Summer is bound to keep you coming back.

4: Soundtrack.

No video game is complete without a soundtrack. Thankfully
helpfulPercent: Sergey Eybog and the band
votesHelpful: Between August and December
votesTotal: spare no expense when it comes to making a great sountrack. Ecah song
votesFunny: coupled with the visuals of the game and the captivating storyline
commentsCount: can send you into a feeling of nostalgia (at least that's what I felt
column16:
having gone to summer camps in my childhood).




So all in all here's the gist of it:



PROS:
Compelling read with branching storyline
Relatable characters each with their own personalities
Soundtrack that fits in with every scene
CONS:
Replaying certain aspects of the storyline tends to get repetitive
The choppy translation from the original Russian game may make things difficult to understand unless to improvise certain lines
Lack of adult content from its Russian predicessor (When will Steam stop with the dang censoring and just use parental conrols?)
With that said I would give it a perfect 10 if it were not for the last two cons. But I definitely give it 9/10."

reviewText:
Based on the lack of price tag and inconsistent art style, you may be tempted to pass up Everlasting Summer out of hand. Don't. While there are certainly aspects of this visual novel you could take issue with or just plain dislike, Everlasting Summer is an obvious labor of love on the part of the developers, one that for the most part paid off.


The story opens with a day in the life of Semyeon, a Russian man who seems to be in his late twenties or perhaps early thirties. Semyeon doesn't do much with his life. In fact, he's the Russian equivalent of the Japanese Hikkikomori: he leaves his apartment solely for the sake of things like buying food before returning to his computer to ♥♥♥♥ around on Russian imageboards. Only one thing separates his life from an ordinary, if reclusive, existence: Semyeon has a recurring dream of life at a form of summer camp that has not existed since the fall of the USSR, designed to make ideal citizens" of its campers.


That is the surreal premise of Everlasting Summer: Semyeon living in a time and place that seems entirely real
date: with no idea how or why he got there or if it is even possible to leave. If you're expecting a full-on psychological horror premise
recommended: don't. While there are unsettling elements to the whole thing and Semyeon never stops being concerned about the fantastic nature of his situation
hoursPlayed: the focus is mostly on romance. In the dream world
voteText: Semyeon is physically but not mentally his 17-year old self. Through interacting with the (mostly female) other campers
helpfulPercent:
Semyeon grows as a person from his initially aimless self in a way that depends on the individual route.


Given the premise
votesHelpful: it would be easy to fall back on simple character archetypes that are a dime a dozen in visual novels and dating sims. To its credit
votesTotal: Everlasting Summer never does that. While initially you might expect every character to be a simple
votesFunny: unaltered form of the archetype they initially appear to be... That would be incorrect
commentsCount: to say the least. Every one of the girls has a decent amount of depth
column16:
and none are entirely what they present themselves as.


The only real faults of Everlasting Summer are highly subjective. If you wanted the horror you might initially expect from the premise
column17: that is fairly limited outside of a few routes designed around it. If you are simply uninterested in visual novels with dating sim tendencies
column18: Everlasting Summer isn't likely to change your mind. If you expect entirely professional and consistent artwork
column19: you won't find that here. If you expect to get through all the routes and endings without occasionally looking at a guide
column20:
good luck with that.


Yet despite or because of its flaws
column21: I truly loved my time with Everlasting Summer and felt compelled to go through as many routes and endings as I could manage. What this visual novel occasionally lacks in proffesionalism given its amateur development team it more that makes up for in heart. Give it a shot."

reviewText:
Here's the deal with this game. It simply should not have been released in English. Not only the translation is mediocre at best, but the developers obviously made a point of appealing to nostalgic feelings of a typical middle-aged Russian. There's a lot of references that only Russians will understand, and without those references the game loses half of its value I think. Not to mention idioms and a play on words on numerous occasions---not even sure how most of those were translated to English (never completed the game in English anyway). Other than that, the game is a beautiful love story with amazing art, good music, and different endings.

Having said that, I would still recommend this game to anyone who likes graphic novels. Being Russian, I certainly enjoyed it myself.

Oh, and don't forget to turn the adult content on (who in the world would make it OFF by default?!)

reviewText: Following in the Russian literary tradition of existentialist works, Everlasting Summer is a multi-faceted triumph of art and entertainment.  Originating from IIchan, Everlasting Summer manages to avoid inauthenticity and pretentiousness that is inherent in image board culture to deliver a visual novel that is truly heartfelt and contains a tone and spirit unlike any other VN currently released.  The plot and themes of the game are relatable to anybody, regardless of age or ethnic background, even if one’s experience is the mirror image or exact opposite of the events within the game.  In a genius move, the division of two realities allows anybody to experience the VN while also engaging in a perspective that differs from their own.  Both existential dramedy and meta commentary on life and entertainment in the post-internet age, Everlasting Summer avoids the cynicism and post-post-post-modern irony found in similar releases of its kind.  While it lacks the biting and irreverent satire of a certain Krautchan VN, it more than eclipses the former with beautiful visuals, an effective multi-genre soundtrack and a genuine sincerity that, combined with the tantalizingly gripping writing style, coalesces into an unforgettable experience that unequivocally stands as the best visual novel released in years.  A flawless English translation means that this hidden gem can be experienced by many, many more people.  Play this as soon as you can; time is precious, as Everlasting Summer eventually makes very clear, and you will certainly not waste or regret any time spent with this.

reviewText:
This is my first Visual Novel EVER. And... i loved it.

I come from post-comunist country, so camps like the one used as setting for this game acually existed and are still standing and decaying here (tho i am not from Russia :D ). I even spent a few weeks one summer in summercamp that proveded acomodation in cabines such as those in the game. It felt really nostalgic (tho i am acually too young to remember comunism it self, facilities like these were still used some time after revolution).
My honest opinion is, that people who lived back then and can remember the summers spent making friends outside and not in front of computer screen, are the ones who will enjoy this game most.

As for the game it self... typical visual novel that isint really lacking anything a VN should have.

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer
At first sight not a very exciting story, but getting more and more interesting: The protagonist Semyon is just an ordinary guy living in a big city.
But suddenly he falls asleep in a bus in winter waking up in a pioneer camp in summer... wait what just happened?!
Spending time in a pioneer camp out of nowhere, meeting new people (indeed girls), exploring places and trying to get out of there... or staying there?

At this point you should expect a lot of monologue and dialogue (like in every visual novel i guess), but it's not getting boring don't worry!

Well.... first of all: I loved that game. Even it has its negative sides" (I don't even know if you can call them so) IT'S FREE! Im very grateful
date:
that I could play it for free.
So let's go ahead.
What I love about this game?
It's weird because its kinda an eroge game (indeed it is lol) but I didn't rly care tbh because I just wanted to play a good visual novel with or without romantic sides. Who think it's just a 0815 dating-simulator

reviewText:
10/10 would change my life again

Everlasting Summer really did open a new chapter in my life. I got deeply interested in visual novels, even though I didn't know a single thing about them before Everlasting Summer. It might not be the best visual novel in the world, but it makes a really good start. The quality is superb if you consider the development time and the community which inspired the whole thing. Yeah, some moments are only understood by /b/♥♥♥♥♥ and Russian nationality people, but the whole atmosphere is purely universal. And it also has Workshop. RenPy is quite simple if you look it up. It means that it's also a great opportunity for all sorts of artistic people. And any herione can easily become your waifu, if you are lonely enough.

By the way, did I mention Workshop?

reviewText:
Despite a premise that initially seems like a Russian spin on the least original AU-fanfic idea imaginable, Everlasting Summer delivers on interesting and complex characters and an interesting and complex meta-plot that unlocks after enough play-throughs.

There is a hentai patch available from the game's website. The art in the hentai patch is of lower quality than the art in the game in general, so I don't recommend it -- it's the equivalent of five or six frames of mediocre fanart.

My one problem with this game is the quality of the character art. It's definitely superior to the art in a lot of free-to-play or cheap VNs, and is at about the same level as some older professional VNs like Fate/Stay Night; however, it doesn't hold up to current standards.

While the setting is a soviet summer camp, no knowledge about soviet culture is strictly necessary.

reviewText:
The plot could be better. The final ending in this game (as any another possible ending trying to explain something) left me quite confused. Maybe it all turned better if endings were a bit more open? Some things does not need an explanation, it's mostly up to player's imagination in such complicated stories.

Some CG-pictures needs fixing. Some character' sprites too.

BUT. In case of this game this is all so secondary, so unnecessary.

Atmosphere. It gets you entirely caught in the process of completing a novel. It never makes you feel bored. Music, backgrounds, many dialogue lines are arranged in such a good order, that at times I was nearly crying like a teenage girl. Heh. Maybe I'm just too emotional. Anyway atmosphere is the best feature of this game. It almost makes you think, that most of this game's media content was borrowed from some professionally made commercial product. And totally no. It all was composed and drawn by a group of freakin' anonymous image board users (Russian imageboard iichan.hk)! Do you believe me?! I was shocked. And yet I was admired by the work done. Yeah they worked on the game for a long time (five years to be precise) but their work was not in vain. It surely counts!

Also checked this novel in English and Russian. In Russian it is EVEN MORE atmospheric. So, cease to impose sanctions for Russia and go learn Russian language! Now! Or you'll never be able to get into it fully!

Well just kidding :) But some typical Russian emotions can't be transferred completely using English. Well-tried.

In conclusion. Those who think that this game is stupid and boring, you must reconsider. Or you are just jealous. Sic!

P.S.: Oh, I forgot, I forgot. There is SO MUCH DUSHA (meaning: love, care, heart) IN THIS GAME.

reviewText: I was not sure what to expect coming into this game. It was a visual novel as anyone could see but as I sat,reading it aloud to a friend, I was blown away from how intrigued I was of the storyline and the relaxing and tranquil art style. It brings a unique sense of feeling, a feeling of nostalgia. The story itself is meant for more mature audiences as I seemed to grasp,not to say it is innappropriate but that the story has some deep meaning, nostalgia, melancholy and may result in serious thinking but good experiences. I have experienced two of the thirteen I believe there is, endings. I was happy with both,one happier and the other seemed a bit unsettling at first but I later learned it was more deep and it had a lot of meaning behind it. The story itself, I believe holds a lot of meaning behind what someone might perceive there to be at first glance or being recently just have started the novel. It started off just as a convenient way to spend time on a winter evening but it turned into a overall satisfying experience and I is why I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in a good read and is looking for a deep story and some beautiful art to go along with it.

reviewText:
Forget that it's an amateur production with some of the roughness you would expect of that, this game impressed me more than plenty of mainstream Japanese VNs.

At a first glance, it's a basic, charming little dating game with a nice variety of routes. The main girls are on a fairly familiar spectrum (kind big sister, genki kid, rebel tsundere, shy yandere) and the short chronological span of the story doesn't allow them much character development, but they're very likable all the same. The unique setting (a late Soviet era youth camp) pulls a lot of weight, managing to be nostalgic even with the cultural oddities. In fact, the cultural oddities were one of the best parts for me; while the game still uses plenty of standard VN/anime tropes, it was nice to see something so different from a generic Japanese High School. Visually, while some of the full-screen CGs do look a little amateur, the character sprites are cute, and the backgrounds and music are really beautiful, also doing a lot for the 'mood' of the game and it's setting.

But there's a lot more here than just the first glance, and this is what makes this game stand out above even some more 'professional' VNs. Each route hints at a bigger picture, and as you move from the 5 basic good endings (and one of the bad endings in particular), to the first and then second bonus routes, and finally to the DLC route, the story becomes increasing psychological and philosophical - and also a bit more heart-wrenching.In fact, the game develops into something that is on par with Higurashi in terms of minscrews and occasional horror. There's also something deliciously meta about the game's plot, as it deals with alternate, repeating realities even as the human at the keyboard loops through multiple new games and save-reloads to see them. YOU are the one tormenting poor Semyon!

P.S. If you make an Olga Dmitrievna route, I'll GIVE YOU MONEY.

She seems like she would have been a better fit for the final route than Yulya, whether as the camp's avatar or itsfirst 'victim'.

reviewText:
I can say with a relative degree of certainty that this is one of the most brilliant things I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. It has a marvelous amout of content, extremely well drawn backgrounds and character designs, lovely music, well developed character personalities, a facinating story, and, I think above all, the ability to evoke profound feelings that I haven't had brought forth by many things, let alone visual novels. Also this particular VN gives its audience the ability to choose, and the choices are many and various.

Depending on your choices, you can influence the story, raise your reputation with various girls, and bring about your future, be it demise or happiness. It is quite immersive, and it's very easy to get absorbed into the enviroment and atmosphere. It is extremely fulfilling to win over a character by getting the good ending, though the bad endings are equally interesting. The story is sectioned off wonderfully, and if you want answers, you must first achieve the task of getting the good ending with all of the girls.

The only qualm I have with this VN is the occasional repetitiveness of beginning a new game after playing through once. I found myself skipping much of the text I'd already read the first time, which can something lighten the deep immersion I felt when first reading the intellectual speculations of Semyon, the protagonist, and the pleasant banter between characters.

Overall, I found Everlasting Summer to be an immensely satisfying and fulfulling experience, and I would recommend it to most anyone.

Plus, there's a catgirl, and who doesn't like those?

reviewText:
7.5/10

I've played a lot of VNs in my time and compared to them, this isn't that good. The story has a bunch of holes and the sprites are not usually what you would find in the average VN (something by Key, Nitro+, 5pb etc); they're more cartoon-like.

Why is it an 7.5/10? I considered the fact that it's a community made VN, similar to Katawa Shoujo, and that there are numerous redeeming qualities of the game. While some of the artwork is sub-par, I find the backgrounds nice to look at. The story is full of holes but is emotionally appealing a.k.a. it's got feels. Story is extremely important to me, more so than art. If you don't think too much about the story, which you shouldn't because VN = multiple routes = certain details revealed on certain routes = inevitable holes, then the VN is extremely enjoyable.

I'm still working on getting all the endings but I'd say the game is worth your time if you're into VNs. I feel like it's not a VN that sells itself solely on the fact that it has nudity and other sex-related aspects in it, but rather with its story. Then again it's not even really selling" itself
date: because it's free.\n\nThe only actual pressing problem I have with this game is that I can't find a text log."

reviewText:
Keept me glued for almost 30 hours now and its free!! It cost you nothing!!

reviewText:
For one thing, it's free, that's not to hate on steam. Another thing is that it isn't at all bad. The Semyon (the protagonist) gets a bit iffy on certain endings but over all the story is pretty enjoyable. It sets up an interesting tone from the start and leaves you wondering, for the most part.

The game also originally launched with erotic content included as it is an eroge, this was removed from the steam version but googling will find a fix for you. I personally prefer the story, TV Tropes post game taught me that.

Over all it's pretty solid.  A good amount of replayablity with 13 endings and a lot of soul put into the game.

PROS:
-Good music
-Good art
-Decent story
-Multiple endings

CONS:
-Lack of automatic resolution selection
-Some minor translation hiccups in a few places
-A certain part can be very confusing to wander through without a map, roughly half way through the game. Breaks the imersion if you need one.

Over all it is not a bad game. It's by no means the greatest. For a visual novel on steam, though, it is pretty competent and I can safely reccomend it. There's not even a risk of money loss as it is free to everyone.

reviewText: I'm shocked this game is free to play, considering the immense depth of it. There are numerous options and multiple endings, both good and bad, giving it a lot of replay value. Aside from that, the character art is wonderful and the backdrops are gorgeous. Though there is no voice acting, the music gives the game plenty of personality. This game was not originally made in English but I am thoroughly impressed with the translation, it's well-written and comprehensible. The story itself is an interesting one, with lots of mystery, humor and drama. The characters are all unique and interesting, and I really appreciate all the inside jokes and nods toward various anime and visual novel sources which gives the game a very tongue-in-cheek attitude.The developers of this game seem truly passionate about their work and connected to the fans of the game, and it shows in the final product. They also continue to add to the story and update with alternate routes and endings, which can also be modified by other users and submitted via the Workshop (which is slowly growing). This feature alone adds endless replayability and also makes the game incredibly unique among other visual novels on Steam. I would love to see more like it.

reviewText: A well constructed visual novel. The game is translated from the original Russian, so it's slightly stilted in parts, but not too badly. It's well worth playing all the good endings, since they tell an overarching (semi) cohesive story. The two Lena endings particularly struck me, with the bad one being heartbreaking and the good one heartwarming. Being a visual novel there are, as expected, erotic scenes, but they're not particularly outlandish. The steam version is censored, but the missing file is available online.

reviewText:
Holy hell... I enjoyed this way more than I probably should have... given I'm a grown man and this deals mostly with teeangers.

At first I was dismayed by the pantyshots (am not into fan-service that much) and erotic depictions of the people, the game could do just as good without them. I overlooked that/tried not to be disturbed by it too much, expected even some heavy hentai at some point, but as I kept reading/watching, I got more and more emotionally involved with the protagonist, who's RL I can relate to quite a lot, and the people he gets to know.

In my first playthrough - and that's what you should do too - I just kept following my intuitions and as such, was rewarded with the intented ending. It's clear that the devs didn't want to primarily make this an 18+ game but the reason for that is there. Only once you get to know the full story and all the characters you might be able to shoot for a different game over scenario.

Especially if you like Manga/Anime, the twists of the story and character adaptions based on your choices make this novel not only great and fun to watch, but just plain awesome - would be fantastic Anime material! It also gave me PSD, and I wish I could forget that I already experienced this and relive it all again... great game".
