reviewText:
A free-as-in-Communism dating sim visual novel,

Everlasting Summer opens with Semyon, a socially isolated 21st-century bachelor — basically a Russian hikikomori — falling asleep on a bus in a cold northern winter. He wakes up on a hot midsummer day on another empty bus, Twilight Zone style. The bus is parked before an idyllic-seeming, picturesque Soviet-era Pioneer youth camp in the middle of nowhere. No driver, no cellphone bars.

Semyon reacts to this mysterious phenomenon by having a panic attack: he curls up in a ball and rolls in the grass wailing WHY ME?" for a while. I'm not totally averse to psychologically damaged protagonists
date: but this is a dating sim. What do the camp girls find appealing about this pathetic self-described loser?\n\nBut when I focused on solving its central supernatural mystery on my first playthrough
recommended: I was hooked by a compelling and creepy story. The game's mysteries only unravel through multiple playthroughs
hoursPlayed: with 13 endings varying greatly in tone from heartwarming to bittersweet to wretched to nightmare fuel. Its most revealing endings only get unlocked after all 6 good endings have been reached.\n\nThe game also has affection for its setting
voteText: evoking such nostalgia for Soviet Pioneer camps than even I
helpfulPercent: a Yank who's never been to the USSR
votesHelpful: felt twinges of sentimentality for them by the time I was through.\n\nExceptional music and background art
votesTotal: but character portraits look quite amateurish. Before playing
votesFunny: I recommend subscribing to and activating Orika's Sprites and CG mod from the Steam Workshop to improve their quality. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=366163610\n\nThe English translation from Russian unfortunately contains many misspellings
commentsCount: malaprops
column16: and grammatical errors that may grate the nerves of sensitive readers
column17: though the intent is usually clear. It helpfully supplies info boxes explaining Russian cultural references for Western audiences
column18: though you're on your own with the anime and sci-fi/fantasy references. (An early joke referencing Ryūgū Rena from Higurashi no Naka Koro ni went right over my head.)\n\nThough Everlasting Summer contains gratuitous cheesecake and sex scenes
column19: dirty pictures have been expurgated from this Steam release. A patch to restore them can be downloaded from the game's website ( http://everlastingsummer.su ).\n\nEverlasting Summer is very unpolished in parts and still has much room for improvement despite its five years of development
column20: but I'll cut it a lot of slack since it's a free VN made by dedicated amateurs. I can't fairly call it good
column21: but parts of it are excellent."

reviewText: It's 3AM and I just finished Miku's route. Do I hate myself? Yes. Did I continuously feel like throwing things out the window whilst playing her route? Yes. Will I finish Ulyana's route to appease my completionist OCD right now? No. Screw that. Maybe I'll touch it sometime next week but I sure as hell am not going anywhere near her for awhile.\n\nI installed Everlasting Summer on a complete whim and didn't expect much at all. Going into it without hope, I was pleasantly thrown in for a loop. The music and the art cards are fantastic (both of which can be listened to/viewed in their appropriate galleries after clearing) and the story is mildly interesting. To be honest, there were quite a few times when the OST smacked me right in the feels and had me wondering if I was facing an existential crisis or not .. The character art style is somewhat awkward and a bit cringe-worthy (at times) but is easily overlookable the more you go down the rabbit hole. There's a downloadable hentai patch" that can supply a nice CG break from what may sometimes feel like ~everlasting dialogue~ and there are enough possible routes/endings to keep you entertained for quite awhile. All in all
date: Everlasting Summer is a surprisingly enjoyable (if not somewhat disturbing) VN that should warrant a try from any fan of the genre
recommended: especially for fans of Higurashi-esque series.\n\nMy only important complaint? Where the hell is the nurse's route?! Sweet Jesus."

reviewText:
If you are reading this, then you are most likely thinking about getting this game. On the surface, it might seem like a pretty average anime styled visual novel with the same plot line as every other similar story.

However, Everlasting Summer is not your typical game with a typical story line.
If you do choose to venture into this game, nothing seems too unusual, but various things will start to transpire as the story goes on. As it is a visual novel, you do have the ability to change your course in the story in order to unlock 13 brilliantly vivid endings. Even though I have only unlocked 4 of these endings at the moment, I can safely say that each of them might torment you in various different ways, whether it be from heartbreak, longing, confusion, or horror. That being said,

THIS IS NOT A GAME FOR THE LIGHTHEARTED

I stress this greatly because I made the mistake of thinking that this would be a fun and happy story as opposed to what it actually is. Without giving away spoilers, if you choose to play this game, be prepared to be creeped out and grossed out at times. (This only actually happens in 3 of the endings that I know of which are perhaps some of least expected and  more difficult ones to unlock, but can be unlocked accidentally nonetheless).

That being said, I still do recommend this game to those who are willing to immerse themselves in this. The interface of the entire game is very well done and even highlights faintly the choices that you did not take before so that you have a chance to uncover a new ending.  In addition, the story lines are spectacular and most of the art is pretty well done. (A few scenes here and there look a little out of place with the rest of the art style, but are not too bad). In addition, the interface of the entire game is very well done and even highlights faintly the choices that you did not take before so that you have a chance to uncover a new ending. Unfortunately, Steam has removed all of the pictures containing adult content, but it fortunately leaves the text alone and does not do much to disturb the actual story lines.

Pros:
Many great storylines
Fun and interesting characters
Nice art style

Cons:
Storyline can get intense at times

Overall: 9.5/10 Definitely would recommend to those willing

reviewText:
A long, detailed visual novel with a good story and multiple paths that actually diverge a lot rather than just make minute changes. Everlasting Summer is a great visual novel game and it's amazing that this game is free.
Through the workshop there are even more stories added.

The good:
-Unique setting (1980s Russia)
-Several girls with their own ending
-Interesting story

The bad:
-Somewhat wonky translation
-No voice acting

Everlasting Summer also definitely earns its Mature rating. If you're a prude, don't even think about playing this.

But for everyone who is not stuck in the Victorian age mentally and who wants to try one of the best examples of a visual novel, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer is a free visual novel. It's a (recurring) story about a man who steps on a bus during the winter, quietly nods off to sleep while an old Soviet melody is playing and... he wakes up alone in the bus at a Russian pioneer camp during the summer.

Story
If you thought that was bizarre, then you're thinking the same thing as our protagonist, Semyon. Are you going to find out what happened to you? Or do you pursue socializing with the local pioneers? With a bunch of routes and endings, Everlasting Summer is sure to give you an interesting experience with a variety of endings.  In the end, there's also a story holding the subsequent playthroughs together. (There's time travel; there's an explanation why you are playing through the game multiple times. This is quite in depth once you hit the final secret routes.) Complete all the endings for the best experience!

Translation
Everlasting Summer was originally a Russian VN, but it has been translated to English. EDIT: Translation is fixed.

Graphics
In terms of graphics, the characters and backgrounds are nicely done, but the CG is inconsistent which can be jarring. But since CG is only a small part of the game, that can be forgiven. (Again, the CG isn't bad, it's just inconsistent with the main style of the game.) The backgrounds are the most impressive and varied.

Soundtrack
The soundtrack contains a ton of tracks. In fact, the soundtrack might be one of the best things about this (free) visual novel. The main theme is memorable and there are some good-sounding tracks. The soundtrack also does a great job giving you the right feeling for each scene.

Conclusion
Regardless, Everlasting Summer is a solid read, and for the amazing price of free, you can't go wrong with this. If you enjoy visual novels this is pretty much a good pick. If you want to give this kind of storytelling (visual novel) a try, this is a good point to start if you can stand the inconsistent art (which is a minor complaint.) The story is pretty damn good so you probably won't mind.

Final verdict: RECOMMENDED

reviewText: For lovers of visual novels.  The story pulls you in and really sinks its teeth into you as you go through the extra playthroughs. reviewText:
I enjoyed this much more that I thought I would.  It's a mostly enjoyable visual novel, with a few gripes and hiccups along the way.

Firstly, the art sits somewhere in the uncanny valley.  At times it looks just fine, then at other times it's just a bit off.  But the backgrounds are often quite detailed and of high quality.

The 4 main heroins all have some problems.  Slavya just kind of generally exists, and isn't very compelling. Ulyana is generally a but too impulsive and often idiotic and immature, but that's kind of the point... or something. Lena is... yeah... this isn't going to be what you expect, and it doesn't feel as well executed as it could have been. Alisa's rout was by far my favorite and the one that I didn't expect to enjoy first going in; the mysterious events that occur on day 4 were much more engrossing and left a more lasting impression, and the ending feels more organic if still a bit stiff.

The extra route for Miku (Almost literally Hatsune Miku) did a wonderful job turning the game on its head. A wonderful surprise to enjoy.

The Final/Harem rout did a pretty good job wrapping up large parts of the mystery and providing more lasting closure to the story.

Add in the DLC extra kinetic novel rout for more story-line shenanigans, arguably the most compelling rout, but it is HIGHLY recommended you play all of the original routes before playing this.

And it's all FREE.

Not the best VN I've ever played, but quite a treat considering the price tag.

I found the English transalation a bit cringeworthy at times. So if you play this and you understand Russian, I would suggest you do so as well. Otherwise it's a pretty good game, and it's FREE ( oh and don't ofget the patch ;) )

reviewText:
Everlasting summer is a free visual novel with 13 major choices. To complete whole game you need about 20  - 30 hours. The game has very deep story about the main hero 25 years old Semyon, who struggle in unknown strange world in Soviet camp in 80s he was sent to. The world itself was not only strange thing, his apperance changed back to 17 years old. The decisions he makes, affects his whole life. Personally I really love this story except part with Lena bad ending. Even though I have completed the game I still wonder about some parts of game to understand it.
Art itself varies from lower to very good quality.
Music is climatic and set up in proper places.
Character design is very well made, every character differs much from other.

To sum up:

Pluses:Very interesting and deep story
Well made characters
Long playability
Free
Many branches"
Minuses:Some of art is bad
No voice acting (sometimes I wonder if it's good or bad)
Music: 10/10
Art: 6/10
Story: 11/10 (In my opinion story is far better then any visual novel I had played)
Translation: 9/10 (For English version)

Overall: 9/10"
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
You know, to be honest I hate visual novels. They never had anything I liked to get me hooked, just really boring. I think they are the worst games, I mean why would you play a book? Just go read it instead.

You know what? I guess I just never played the right one. Everlasting Summer is that one. Some of the girls, (we most) do feel like your carbon-copy harem types, but for some reason this is just different. Maybe it is because the game is Russian and I am playing on Japanese Harem Stereotypes. But to be honest, I do recommend this game. It is free, so there is no reason not to try. The game was built for completionist, (I being one), in fact, the last ending depends on you completing all the others first. Which was nice, because it gave me the closure on the story. It explained it, and left a good message on what the purpose was. I cannot tell you it, because I want you to go find out yourself, trust me the game is worth it.

You know, I was recommended to play this by random, but if I didn't start off with a great character (I went Alisa first), I may not a gotten so hooked. But I want you to try it, and just see who you like. You will laugh, or at least smile for some. You may be creeped out in others (trust me it happens). Or, you may even cry by the end. But trust me, I did all. And this is coming from someone who would tell most to turn away from visual novels, but now I am telling you to try this one.

I hope this was helpful,

Thank you for your time,


Strewberry98-RiskyMcDangerfield.

reviewText:
Whatever satisfies the soul is truth.Walt Whitman

Where the hell am i?
This game makes me almost speechless. I can't describe how unbelievable the story is. Like other visual novel, i only can recommend this interactive book if you're interested in reading. One story-part takes several hours (i spend nearly 7-8 for only one story-part). There are 13 endings which are all different. Some can have an happy end, other endings can be really depressing. Which ending do you get decides your relationship to the girls which you will meet, and your relationship goes up or down with your decisions.

So many girls...
On your journey you will meet some girls. All of these girls have their own personalities which is very different to the other ones. So every moment with one of these girls creates its own atmosphere and emotions.

Wait, how much endings?
All endings are unique, but which ending is the true ending? Is there a true ending? Without spoiling i only can say, play till the very end. Play to the last ending. It's worth it. After you get the last ending you will see a large whole which will amaze you.

Need I say more?
This game has an fantastic Soundtrack, so some great songs will awaits you and if you play all options, which the game offers you (different decisions, visited places, etc.), you will get lots of fantastic artworks too. If you want to see all artworks (includes the missing erotic scenes), look for the patch in the steam-community.

To bring bring it to the point: phenomenal visual novel and it's for free! 9,5/10

In summary:
Pro        Contra                + many endings        - no voice acting                + interessting charakters                + unbelievable story                + many decisions                + workshop for additional stories etc.                + free to play

PS: I just wanted to write a short review, which brings the essence of the game to the point. I hope it will help you in your decision.

reviewText: A complete 10/10 hidden gem! While its considered to be a visual novel, it plays more like a choose your path story game. It has various levels of emotion depending on what choices you pick. It entertwines several genres such as romance, drama, a little bit of horror, adventure, some comedy, and a very few times, action. The concept is an extremly deep idea, and it only keeps you wondering more and more. And it will probably keep you wondering about your life. There are multiple endings too.  Some really horrible, others bad, 1 or two neutral, and a couple very good ones.

reviewText:
Since Steam has been adding more visual novels and dating sim games, i looked for some and decided to try out this one because it was free and i was in a dating sim kind of mood.

Pros:

-Free to Play, emphasis on FREE
-Gorgeous Scenery and backgrounds
-Interesting story (at the time of this review and only on Day 5)
-Hatsune Miku (or at least a character who really resembles her, which is probably why this game is free to play due to copyright)
-The following characters are interesting and/or easy to get along with. Somewhat typical and expected of a dating sim game, but the better charcaters of this game (at the time of the review): Alisa, Slavya, Lena, Miku
-Nice looking female characters (as expected of a dating sim, but especially nice since everyone's wearing identical costumes). the character designs are a good in between; not too extreme but not too generic.
*** - The creators of the game proofread the English version, so most of the typos and lose English is fixed, though you may still occasionally see Alisa's name listed as Alice in some dialouge boxes. For those who've already played the game or have old save files however, you may not be able to fast-forward as much as you want because the new English Proofread dialouge counts as 'unseen' text that you may not be able to skip past.
- Semyon is a very interesting character. You play the game from his point of view but he's very different from other dating sim male leads i've played as thus far. He actively questions what's going on around him and i've often found myself relating to him in the various situations he gets himself in and feeling the same way toward the girls he intereacts with (for better of for worse). He's very smart for a player-avatar character and i wish more of these types of characters come to future dating sims (especially when the lead is a female).
-  Depending on which girl you pursue, you'll find that the story's genre may even change (at least that's how i saw it). Different things will happen, some things will have been real, other things will have just been a beautiful dream, you may even see that your dreams came true in some form should Semyon wake up at all. It makes me want to get all of the endings and achievements to see what's actually Semyon's reality and what's his dream! BRAVO DEVS, BRAVO!


Cons:

-If you're a grammer Nazi, good luck reading this game in English... Everything from simple typos to ordering of words and even character names can be messed up (most notable with Alisa, whose name can appear as Alice in the dialouge box) ***
-No gay routes, only hetero routes (though because this game is originally Russian, I can't exactly blame them for that)
-All of the characters with the exceptions of the ones i mentioned above... ARE ANNOYING AND/OR DATING SIM STEREOTYPES. Ulyana is an extremely annoying child (why can no one ever write a child character that isn't the devil, annoying or both?), Olga is extremely bossy (if i read the phrase 'line-up' one more time i might stab my computer screen and i think Seymon feels the same way), Electronik and Shurik are typical male characters in dating sims in that they either encourage hooking-up, force the player into doing something they normally wouldn't do or just being in the background compared to the main female characters of the game. And of the two other male characters, i find that only Electronik is helpful and at least somewhat interesting.
-All of the female character's I've mentioned in the con's part of the review also seem to suffer from the rapidest of mood swings. Olga is nice one second, the next second she's like a dictator; Ulyana is still extremely annoying and Zhenya seems to go from a nuetral mood to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off for no reason within seconds. You may argue that the tsundere of the game, Alisa, also has these rapid mood swings but at least hers are enjoyable to watch and read and she isn't as bossy as Olga and  her moodswings are explained somewhat in her route as well as hinted at in Lena's . In addition Alisa has her sweet/adorable moments unlike any of the female characters i've mentioned in the cons.
- After a while you feel like you're dragging Semyon through one event after the other. You are given some choices which will help you in getting the different endings but after a few playthroughs you already know you'll have to do certain tasks without any yes or no and you'll be forced to do them over and over again. It'll feel like a pain after a while, but this is remedied somewhat because Semyon is very nice and relatable (at least to me).
-This game's setting is set in a time during the USSR, which makes a history-lover like myself want just a little more history in the game or at least some more history trivia


Overall, this game is free to play and so i can complain all i want, but hey i payed nothing for it. The annoying characters are still annoying as hell, the other male characters just seem to be there for the sake of being there like typical 'best friend' male characters in these kinds of games, the English translation was proofread and the text is easier to read now. And the characters who i mentioned in the Pros are enjoyable and easy to get along with. AND IT'S STILL FREE!

I give this game 4.5 beautiful summers out of 5

reviewText: A complete 10/10 hidden gem! While its considered to be a visual novel, it plays more like a choose your path story game. It has various levels of emotion depending on what choices you pick. It entertwines several genres such as romance, drama, a little bit of horror, adventure, some comedy, and a very few times, action. The concept is an extremly deep idea, and it only keeps you wondering more and more. And it will probably keep you wondering about your life. There are multiple endings too.  Some really horrible, others bad, 1 or two neutral, and a couple very good ones.

reviewText:
I didn't really enjoy the main line of the plot, kinda silly, and I have to tell you that it was hard for me to sympathize with the main character: the standard apathetic anti-social teenager (though he is an adult, theoretically) with a sarcastic sense of humour and lack of patience for anything.

I actually disliked the writing style in english, and I don't know how it feels in other languages. In my opinion, it was way too verbose and unnecessary at many points, specially when the main character is talking to himself. Alone. Like... a lot. I almost quit at the beginning.

In spite of those near-showstoppers, the game is good, and that's because of the OTHER characters, they have quite of a depth in them. It was fun to try to figure out how to get the good ending" with each girl (I gave up on some and looked for a guide). There are many options

reviewText:
After unlocking every single acievement in the game and playing through the whole thing I am very satisfied in playing this game. If you don't like reading books but would like to hear a great story this video game is right for you. It's very well written and has 13 alternative endings that you can get.

The game has alot of mystery packed into it. It would leave you to go to differents ending to uncover more mysteries of the game. And if you do happen to unlock most of the endings and finally go through the ending with the cat-eared girl, it's very satisfying to wrap all of things you did in the game. The scenery is great too and the endings arn't the same.

My favorite ending was Lena's. Both bad and good. And the Harlem ending too.

reviewText:
An Everlasting Summer Indeed.. Achievements: 14/14
Expected: 20-30 hours to complete.
Endings: 13

If you're a avid Visual Novel player, this is worth playing and 100%ing.
Also if you like and watch a lot of anime you might recognise some of the references, if you're lucky you might notice a few familiar distinguishing features in the background when you're in the canteen ;)

The next line will have minor spoilers to the story. If you don't want to be spoiled a little, only read up to Nudity then go to the next paragraph.

What to expect:  Anime babes | Romance | Mystery | Nudity <-check around | Horror <-Yes I said horror  (worth finishing)

So we begin..

At first, I was reluctant to click on the Store Page due to the game's picture being in a different language, but saw that the screenshots were in English and so decided to give it a chance.
This is not the first Visual Novel I have played, I had alreadly experienced a variety of Visual Novels but it was the first that went like that.

This game will change your views on a lot of things, and one playthrough is not enough. Finishing all endings was actually quite satisfying. Even now, I play now and then for the fun of it. Trust me. Your perspectives will change.

I WAS hint the past tense. severly disappointed that Miku was portrayed as a annoying splinter in your backside with Semyon trying all in his power to avoid any possible future encounter with her by being cold and leaving prematurely as when she's still talking. But I have to say that was pretty hilarious. That hasn't at all changed the rating or recommendation of this review, it compensated it with comedy.

Worth playing, and there's nothing to lose.
Recommended (Y)

reviewText:
I can't really add anything that hasn't been said several thousand times in the multitude of reviews so far. Over 11,000 positive reviews and less than 700 negative reviews on a free game isn't just a sign, it's a wake up call to everyone.

Play this game. Play it over and over again. It's not a typical dating sim in the slightest. While I do refuse to spoil even the slightest bit of this game, I can't emphasise this enough. It certainly looks like one on the surface and takes a while to really get to the juicy bits, but there's no reason everyone shouldn't give this game a shot. The plot once you dive in is nothing short of mind-bending.

Don't expect to get every reference unless you lived in the USSR during the era this game takes place. But don't let that stop you from enjoying what I will happily call one of my top three favorite games of 2015. (Yeah, I was late to the party.)

12 and a half hours is what it took me to see everything. Every normal ending, two bad ends, and the several secret endings. I did use the auto-skip function quite a bit, but only because the early portions of the game are similar for most routes.

reviewText: I've never really played any visual novels before this. I'm not much into anime. Some friends in my GMod community had played through some of this and it seemed like an interesting story. I get it on a whim (it is free after all) and I can say that I'm beyond impressed. The character development, the plot(s), the artwork, and everything are amazing. It still has some minor imperfections in translation, but damn, I've never felt as much of a connection to a game as I have this. It's exactly like reading an incredible book but with visuals. I still have most bad endings to complete, but I'm going to be sad when I've gone through this VN because it keeps beckoning me back to play more. And best of all, it's free. Do yourself a favor and play this.\n\nAs for the future, there are some things that would be nice to see in future updates. Proofreading will be patched soon it seems. I would like to see a Zhenya and/or Olga ending, maybe even an Elektronik or Shurik ending that those who roll that way would like (or just to see how the plot would go in that case) Regardless, I can't say enough good things. Get this VN.

reviewText:
Whoa boy, how to properly describe this.
Do you remember when you were young?  Do you remember summer nights, awkward teenage romance, days that last forever, but seem to end before you know it?
This 'game' is a romance visual novel set in, of all places, a Soviet-era youth summer camp, where the protagonist somehow ends up after boarding a bus in modern-day Russia.
If you've ever played a visual novel before, you know how it works, click through the text, making choices when it lets you, watching the character and background art slide by, like raindrops down a window.
The aforementioned art is nothing special, in fact it gets straight amateurish at times, and sometimes it's enjoyable, but nothing too special.
The soundtrack is beautiful, properly reinforcing the moods of the scenes, and sticking with (at least me) you for a while after playing.
The characters are variable in execution, and tend to lean on archetypes a little much, but they all have their own little ticks that make them stand out.
The real meat of what this is, however, isn't in the art, the story itself, or even the beautiful soundtrack.  It's in the overall atmosphere, the sense of long-gone summers and those young romances that are almost too awkward to bear, yet you wouldn't change them for the world.  It's the nostalgia emanating from every earnest pore of this freeware VN, made by -chan anons over several years, much like the lauded Katawa Shoujo.
If you're the type to get misty-eyed over graduation slideshows, songs like Summer of '69, Good Riddance (Time of your Life) or to keep a photo album, or if you're in the mood for an amateur, if earnest and heartfelt, romance story.  I'd reccommend spending a few hours clicking through.
(Just not Miku's route, GabeN save us from that horror...)

reviewText: Everlasting summer is a fun, sad, and sometimes really dark dating sim. You will meet the cute blond, the shy one, the bully, the little annoying sh**, the egg head, friend of egg head, etc. The game has a good art style and fine music. It also has alot of references both to russian culture and pop culture *tf2, strategy games, and even a japanese pop star :3*. While its not a game that your gonna regret not playing in your life, it is a fun time if you like dating sims or is new to them. If i could complain about one thing is that some of the characters gets almost no screen time compared to others, or at least thats how it was doing my run. The game also has a gallery with diffrent pictures depending on which route you take. Its free so you won't have to fear wasting your money

reviewText: EDIT: I wrote the review below, and yet within 24 hours returned to the game. My experience was entirely different, and I came to love it. The thing is.... it's not a game about romance. Not really. And while I had a fictional-character-crush on Alisa and wanted a more satisfying ending, that's really not what this game is about. It's about mystery, about understanding who one is and choosing whether or not to chance. The girls are there, and you can indeed romance many of them.... but it's about the self-revelation one has by spending time with them. In dialectical terms, they are the antithesis to the thesis of your main character's status quo, and the exploration of these storylines produce the synthesis you end with. Romance can be a part of it, but in a way, it can also be extraneous because it's about a transformation of the self and the choice between living a flavorless, reclusive life and one of joy and abundance.   So far as I've yet seen, there's not so much a  trite she made me a better man"
date: as the contrast of a girl's character and the interactions you have giving the main character a new perspective if he chooses to look. From this vantage

reviewText: I don't usually like to read. I also don't usually like Visual Novels. Or spelling errors for that matter but even so. Everlasting Summer was a great read. I played through it so many times trying to get every good ending possible, but the first read through had to be the best. Going through every decision from my own point of view on how i would handle it. The story was more engaging that first read through and I think that is what got me hooked and wanted to find out every other ending. I highly recommend Everlasting Summer to anyone who even glances at it with time on their hands to kill.

reviewText: This is an amazing game, I cannot believe this game is free! Now, the closest thing I ever played that could be called a visual novel is the walking dead but this is so much more. It's a good story, with some excellent writting although the english version is filled with typos but that only adds to the humor. The girls are pretty unique and the options you get are interesting. Playing this game, is liking putting yourself in another world for a time and then comming out. The best part of all, its free! The creators of this game put so much work into something they wouldn't even make money off of! Now to me, thats committment! It's amazing to see a Russian Anime and see all the details and work done for a game that costs nothing. I have now played through all the endings and I am completely amazed at how intense some of them are. The game puts you through a whole barrage of emotions: laughter, tears, screams during the scary ending, and awe at how some things go. To the creators of this game, thank you! Thank you for a great novel and for sharing your dream with everyone! You should play this game, you won't regret it!

reviewText: Бесконечное Лето - отличная индея для различных модов и фанфиков. Как бы странно это ни звучало, мне намного больше нравятся всяческие моды на тему бесконечного лета. Сам оригинал-источник - так себе. Пройдя все концовки линейной игры, мне так никто и не полюбился из персонажей кроме главного героя. Хоть Семёна и не видно почти, но вот к нему я привязался. Ход его мыслей, как он потихонечку офигевает от всего происходящего и т.д. Все девочки будто куколки - никогда не знаешь когда тебе воткнут нож в спину.\nА насчет модов - это уже отдельная история. Столько интересных модов, что во все не успеешь поиграть. Единственное, что я могу сказать с уверенностью это то, что в бесконечное лето стоит поиграть ради модов ну и вдохновения (для того, кто постоянно что то пишет да сочиняет).

reviewText:
It's free and it's not a waste of your time. You should give this game a try, whether you're a fan of visual novels or a beginner to the genre. Everlasting Summer has a very nice story, but you'll have to go through five playthroughs or so to get it. This can get tedious, especially since many dialogues and events repeat themselves even when you're on a different route. Fortunately, there is a fast-forward button so you don't need to manually click through them. This game also has very nice-looking graphics. It incorporates both the anime/manga and comic/cartoon style art.

While the characters are generally likable, the MC could get annoying at times. And you might be tempted to skip through some of his monologues, which is fine. A major problem with this game is that it's rife with grammatical errors and typos, and some people could find this frustrating. However, they're not so bad as to make the writing incomprehensible.

reviewText:
First of all, this game is quite good. Far better than you can expect from the game made by the large group of unorganized people.
Art is a little bit various from screen to screen. Backgrounds are beautiful, characters sometimes rough, sometimes OK, sometimes good. Overall, i can say that while having some good artists among the devs, this game lacks art-direction.
The storyline - a totally different situation. Story is good, it has some well-made WTF-moments, and it really takes several playthroughs to figure it out. The protagonist is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and a lot of dialogues are awkward, but this story has it's own charm. It takes some time and effort to see it.

The game was initially written in russian, and english translation is not as good as the original text. But it seems that they are working to improve it.

Music is amazing. Including some soviet-themed tracks.

Some say that this game is a hentai dating sim. That's not actually true. Though the game has some adult content (but not in Steam version), the game is good enough without it. Maybe even better. And it's totally not a sim, due to very little amount of choices. It's what it is - a good story with a little bit of interaction.

The game is free. Really free, no microtransactions, no strings attached.

Worth your time, if you ask me.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is.. certainly something.

Despite the adult rated scenes (which have been removed from the steam version, but can re-added to the game with some trickery) and the grammatical errors/inconsistencies in the English translation, it is actually surprisingly insightful. The story is interesring, the characters are likeable and each of them has different quirks and behaviors. Regardless of which path you choose, this game will leave you with a bittersweet taste which will make you come back to it just because you want to experience more of it.

It's not terribly long so it's perfect for people who want to get into simple Visual Novels as a genre, it is fun, spooky at times, interesting and a single playthrough won't let you touch all the details and hidden events that happen at the magical Sovionok camp.

I definitely recommend this game, play it, it's free and it will be a memorable experience.

reviewText: Everlasting Summer is a visual novel that advance to one of multiple endings based on your choices. I loved this game very much, it has a lot of entertaining scenes and a lot of surprising moments. I like that it let's you choose your path, but some of the parameters for certain endings, especially Ulyana's good ending, are so specific that you practically have to look at the walkthrough. And a walkthrough doesn't necessarily hurt after your first two or three endings. I certainly recommend this game and would encourage players to download a certain file (found here https://vk.com/topic-62816733_31120658) and install it back to the game files. I enjoyed almost every minute of this, and would also suggest Alisa's alternative ending, found on the Steam workshop, after completing all other endings.

reviewText: Everlasting Summer is definitely one of the most memorable VNs I've played in a while. I absolutely recommend it to fans of the genre. What sets it apart, for me, is that it actually has a storyline that attempts to give an in-game explanation for the visual novel game mechanics that encourage you to replay multiple times to experience the different routes. And replay you should, as this VN has a definitive end that you can only get by completing all the good" routes. Not to mention there's one route that was pretty terrifying. I came for feels

reviewText: This is only the second visual novel I've played, and the first was several years ago. It was a good re-introduction to this game genre, and won't be the last I play. The protagonist is Semyon, a 25ish reclusive guy living in a city in modern (21st century) Russia, who falls asleep on a bus and wakes up to find he's at a summer camp in the Soviet Union.\n\nThere are too many good points to list them all here, and I hope I don't forget any of the most important ones. The music (by Sergey Eybog, and by Between August and December) is outstanding and does an excellent job of setting the mood. The character art and backgrounds are all very well done. The gallery" images are of inconsistent quality but many are very good. But that's all dressing - a visual novel

reviewText:
You'll wear out your mouse button clicking through every line of dialogue and exposition in this game; it's given to you single sentence by single sentence. It's worst in the game's prologue, when you're doing nothing but clicking through Semyon's dreary restlessness.

This is a visual novel, and the bulk of the story is your life at a Soviet youth camp, where you spend a few days trying to catch up on sleep, trying to make it to meals on time, and trying to do all the tasks that the camp coordinator gives you. But the story is given plenty of time to develop, and you're given lots of opportunities to get to know the other campers - most of whom are attractive young women with somewhat stereotypical personalities. The character artwork looks more like something from DeviantArt than professionally done, but the backgrounds are gorgeous, and the sound fits the mood.

But it's the end of the story where things get interesting and set the stage for another go-through (or several more). Unfortunately, given the sheer length of time it takes to click through the story sentence-by-sentence, once is enough for me.

reviewText: I came seeking feels and a deep experience and came away with neither...but thats not exactly a bad thing.  This one is definitely worth your time.  Having just finished Katawa Shoujo i was looking for something similar and was recommended this VN.   Katawa Shoujo this game is not.  The setting and the playfulness of it is what really kept me interested.  The main problem i had with the story is that you never really get to know any of the heroines.  Although you spend a couple of days with them doing all kinds of stuff, you dont get to delve deeper into who they really are as in KS.  All in all a worthwhile read with some of the best looking backgrounds ive ever encountered in a VN.\n\nUpdate:  WOW!  Just finished the DLC Zhenya route and it really makes the whole journey complete.  A complete mindbender with some feels thrown at me in the end.  Good stuff guys.  Excellent work.  Please if you play through this game do every last bit for the whole effect, trust me its worth it.  Thanks for the ride guys.

reviewText: This is an excellent Visual Novel, one of the best I've played on steam so far. The story and characters are fascinating, and the main character is very easy to relate to. The english translation is a little rough around the edges, however I don't mind it did not effect the story for me. Since it has a lot of choices it seems the game will be highly replayable which is rare for a visual novel. Overall I highly recommend it, and why not give a try its free after all.

reviewText:
Everlasting Summer was a charming, mystifying treat . . . especially because it was FREE.  And HOLY WHAT my nonexistent dollars certainly went a long way this time.  I'll pay nothing all day to visit a strange anime Soviet Russian alternate reality, where for some reason I become the object of numerous cute girls' affections.  Though things are not nearly so simple as that.

Yar, this be a visual novel / dating sim, but the storyline and artwork make it a deeper endeavor.  The story is at times dreamy, occasionally erotic, and at times outright creepsterish.  I found myself heart broken and with a vivid sense of longing.

Very enjoyable gamepay but quite casual.  All you do is click your mouse button and read and look at half-naked anime chicks.  Oh well, I like to read.  AND ALL FO FREE.

There are lots of cute gals to chat up, and the artwork is rather charming.  Lots of blank screens though, making me question whether there is an uncensored version lurking about somewhere. . .

There are multiple endings to attain, all of which have achievements.  This makes it worth the multiple play-throughs for all those achievement junkies like me.  The endings are unique and vary greatly in where your character ends up.  Also, during multiple play-throughs, you have the ability to fast-forward through game sequences you have already experienced, and it automatically stops when you reach a part you haven't seen yet.

Knowing what I know now, I would pay for this game.  But I don't have to, and neither do any of you.  Because it be free.

reviewText:
this game...holy ♥♥♥♥ this game. Usually I'm not a fan of reading or virtual stories but holy ♥♥♥♥ is this game ♥♥♥♥ing incredible. I say this because of the immersion and character developement of the different people around you during those seven days. This game has some incredible story telling worthy or ranking above and beyond Life is Strange and The Walking Dead. There is also some amazing content and hidden story for the theorists of the world to uncover about this game like: where you are, why you are here and what this place is. The game also had some very creepy and dark themes to it like the old camp grounds which you visit on day 4. The diversity of all the characters and seeing them all thrown into one place just made the 'game' so much more enjoyable.

Cons- Of course no game is without its problems so here are a some of the problems I found.
dificult to find specific endings for characters alone, the game has some incredible points in the story which it doesn't elaborate in too much detail and I found it difficult to 'like' some of the characters introduced.

Overall I highly reccomend this game to EVERYONE even if its just to try it out or 'go out on a limb.' the game portrays and excellent contrast with the Russian setting compared to Russia at the time. This game is PERFECT for anyone even if you're not a fan of these types of games seeing as its a much more relaxed and calm experience which can still get very tense or creepy. So go download this game and PLAY IT, I cannot reccommend this game anymore

reviewText:
Back in Soviet era, was not only war that was frozen solid, so too was my heart. My head warmed by good ushanka, body by thick clothes crafted by the calloused hands of the people, tough boots kept out the damp of pure Russian snow, yet still on the inside I was cold like relations between East and West. Perhaps had I access to visual novels rather than the writings of Fadeyev and Mayakovsky I’d have my insides would have thawed, my heart melted and run through my veins as tears ran from my eyes when I first –Passage redacted by party- or the the time I –Passage redacted by party- or even the fear that chilled me colder than the Siberian nights when –Passage redacted by party-


Instead I worked and slept and slept and worked, my sweat the sweat that fell from my brow greasing the wheels of the revolution as I helped push forward the glorious machine of the People’s revolution. I did not think it was bad life, and perhaps it was not, but had I been able to make choices between seven futures as this game allows you to choose between seven women, perhaps I’d now be drowning in the warmth brought by a life fulfilled and not the warmth brought by good vodka.

reviewText:
Everlasting summer is a visual novel from developers Soviet Games aka Erogame Project released in 2013. It is currently available in Russian, English and Spanish.

Story:
The story revolves around our protagonist Semyon, in his mid-twenties, who seems to have given up on life. But one day he ventures to the 410th bus and boards it, only to wake up outside a pioneer camp. Now he must find a way out while living a week in the camp.
Most of them time the story feels like the usual slice of life/romance VN but it really shines when the main focus is on Semyon trying to find out why he is at that pioneer camp and how to get back home. The whole story, including the different paths and endings, is at a decent length with about 15-20 hours of playtime.

Writing (English version):
The writing is ok for the most part. There are some typos and grammatical errors but nothing too distracting, also the developers native language is not English so these mistakes can be forgiven.

Characters:
The characters are likeable and their interactions with each other is quite enjoyable. On the surface all the characters are quite generic stereotypes (energetic, shy, etc.) but they always seem intriguing and that there is more to them.

Art:
Is a mixed bag for me. I really like the backgrounds, sprites and overall character design. The problem I have with the art are the CGs. Some of them are just bad, some make the characters look different and just a few of them are really good.

Soundtrack:
Not much to say here. For me, there are no songs that stand out but on the other hand I wasn't annoyed of any of them either. Most of the time the songs match the scene nicely and that's what is most important.

Overall:
I'd recommend Everlasting Summer. Besides its flaws there is an intriguing story with likeable characters and a satisfactory ending.

And it's FREE, so why not give it a try?
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Hands-down THE best free visual novel on Steam, and in heavy contention with most of the paid ones too! It's certainly something different from the norm, eschewing the tired and repetative Japanese high school setting for a Soviet Young Pioneer camp and the art, while anime-inspired, is still a markedly unique and attractive style.

The story is truly vast, with half a dozen different routes which, although they take a while to diversify, are all unique and interesting and mostly not that frustratingly difficult to unlock. The characters are fantastic and appealing and you're sure to come away from the game with a favourite, whether it's spunky rocker Alisa or cheerfully bratty little-sister-type Ulyana (I never thought I'd say this, but Slavya is my waifu). There is the odd unanswered question left even once you reach 100% completion (like what the hell happened to Shurik or what was with that dream about the underground bunker?) but overall it's a classic story- or several classic stories, as is the case with the best VNs. Additionally the game benefits from a truly great English translation from the original Russian script, written by an exceedingly talented and handsome writer who has a great future ahead of him.

Oh alright, it was me.

But in my defence I played the game to completion BEFORE I volunteered my talents to rewrite the honestly very dodgy original translation, so it's not just bias talking here. In fact you can take that as proof of what a fantastic VN this is- I wouldn't have put dozens of (unpaid) hours into rewriting the 2000+ page script of just ANY game after all!

Technically speaking the game is fantastic as well. The art is beautiful and the characters are gorgeous, and the soundtrack (especially the morbid but rocking opening theme) is fantastic. For a free game made by a fan collaboration (the group who call themselves Soviet Games), it's a cut above the usual standard. The full version of the game (which, incredibly, was the version initially released onto Steam) also features gorgeous sex scenes (which bypass the classic problem of cringe-worthy Ikea Erotica descriptions by being told in only a few still images) which can be restored easily enough with the right patch (readily available from the Discussion Forum). The game also supports Community Workshop content (although most of it is sadly in untranslated Russian) and even some free DLC in the Zhenya route to give you that much extra content if you want it.

Ultimately Everlasting Summer is a triumph. Not only by FAR the best pure free visual novel on Steam (only Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius tops it, and that's a VN/strategy hybrid), it's also one of the best VN's I've ever played, PERIOD (and I've played dozens of VNs in my time). It's truly the Russian equivalent of Katawa Shoujo, and every bit as worthy of your time. If you're a fan of visual novels, you HAVE to play this game, and I mean that literally. If you don't play this game, you don't truly appreciate VNs. Play it. Now.

Can't wait for the team's first professional  effort, 'Love, Money, Rock'n'Roll'.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
FeelingsEvery story has its beginning and its end. Every story has its own outline, synopsis, key points, a prologue and an epilogue. And there is no book which, if you read it again, would not reveal new details you didn't notice before. Every story has its beginning and its end. Almost every...

I picked up Everlasting Summer in early January 2016, because I was bored and curious what kind of game this is. I had never played a visual novel before, so I didn't really know what to expect, but this game completely got to me.

You play as this man in his late 30s who has a boring life, he is anti-social and spends most of his time alone on his computer in his flat. He goes to a class reunion and falls asleep in the bus. When he wakes up he notices he in a 1980s Russian pioneer camp. He also turns out to be 17 years old again. He is far away from home, in a different reality even. He stays there for a week and then goes home with the same bus (or doesn't he?).

It seems that he lives the same week in the camp over and over again. When he tries to leave after a week, he wakes up in the camp again and the whole story restarts. Can he get out? Does he even want to get out? He is the only real human in the fake reality in which he ended up.

In this camp he meets all kind of different characters, most of them are girls and he can get attached to them. This leads up to 13 different endings, which take quite some time to complete, but are very story rich and interresting. I would say it is kinda a mind♥♥♥♥ story, if you have done several endings at some points you simply don't know what reality is anymore.

The music is very beautiful and probably the best part of the game, combined with the story. The artwork is good as well, but not amazing-like.

The reason the title of this review is ''Feelings'', is because the stories really get to your feelings and this was the main reason I kept playing this game.

For example; there is an ending where you commit suicide, there is an ending in which you end up playing in a band and there even is a horror ending where everyone dies. You can simply choose not to play this last path, if you're not into horror.

When you've finally completed the game in 100%, which means playing all endings (believe me, it's worth it), you can download several mods and DLC which is a nice extra. I think this adds up to around 30 hours of gameplay, or if you're a fast reader, perhaps a bit less.

And the best part of it all, it's free! I would've paid money to play this game, if I knew it was this good. It's great to see there are still awesome free games like this available.

All in all it's a great visual novel game with beautiful music, very interresting and emotional stories and best of all, it's free. Don't hesitate in trying out this game, it's worth it.

9.5/10

reviewText:
This is easily one of the best Visual Novel's i've seen on steam in all my years. I've heard people giving it a hard time because the graphic style is a bit different, and the setting is out of the ordinary.

I found it to be refreshing, something new to add to the Genre itself.

The endings were interesting, but only three stood out above the others, and that was Miku, Harem, and Lena's endings.

Had i worked with the group i would of suggested more endings like that of Lena's.

I had a blast playing it and going through the gallery again, I can safely say i'll likely play through it and wrap it 100% again in the near future.

The mod community is quite active and my only nit picks about the game are fixed with that.

Creative, imaginitive, only a few short comings and you can't beat the price (free).

Knowing what i do now about the whole thing, i wish i had paid for it, as its definitely the best deal i've ever had on steam.

Music was perfect for the story, I think i vaguely remember crying for one of the endings like a little ♥♥♥♥♥. The characters were the best part and in the end i felt like i wished there was more... so I'm going to see if i can help with the community to make more for it.

I'd say check out the various mods and if you enjoyed Alisa, check out It not a dream" which i helped with the translation of!

Oh... Right... I rate it 10 Motherland's!

PS. Because of this game I'm actually trying to learn Russian so i can be active in the workshop mods to translate some of them to english. Already worked on one as best i could and made some good friends because of it."

reviewText:
I'm gonna be showing both pros and cons (As long as I can think of some), but I will say that I highly recommend this game right off the bat.

Need more persuasion? Alright.

But first, lemme get something straight here. Everlasting Summer is a visual novel. It's focus isn't on gameplay, it's about the story. And Soviet Games has made a damn good one here.

Anyway, lemme make a very basic outline of the plot (No spoilers).

The main character, Semyon, is... a guy. He's a person who believes he has no special qualities and hardly sees a point to life. Then, one day, when he gets onto a bus, he is transported to the Sovionok Pioneer Camp. Here, he meets various girls and boys as well as finding out more about 'life'.

The plot sounds rather unbelievable, but it explains itself very well, with the 'unlockable' endings later on in the game providing more of an insight into what's going on in the camp.

Anyway, here are the main pros and cons.

Pros
- A great, well-explained story with next to no plot holes (It might be a little head-scratching at first, however).
- A beautiful, diverse cast each with distinct personalities.
- Very well made background images and character sprites.
- An AMAZING soundtrack.
- Feels.
- It's free.

Cons
- A slightly confusing story opening (But like I mentioned, it sorts itself out shortly after).
- Very specific actions are required to get certain endings (I had to look up a guide for one of them).
- Some slight mess ups with the Russian to English translation. It is still perfectly readable however, and Soviet Games have said they are working on a revised translation.

In conclusion, Everlasting Summer is a great visual novel that will leave you in tears (Of both joy or sadness, depending on the ending). It's managed to give me many hours of fun so far and I expect that to happen for a while longer. A great read.

9.5/10

reviewText:
This game is worth playing, but be warned -- your choices will hardly effect your outcome. I played the game normally once and ended up with a bad ending, made one small change near the end of the game and ended up with a good ending, and then made all of the opposite choices than my first playthrough (but still the same last choice) and got the same good ending. I may have to consult a walkthrough to get more achievements for this game, or keep clicking random buttons -- thank goodness for the built-in fast-forward feature that knows which options you have already chosen, and lets you speed past text you've already read, I am thankful for that.

All in all -- this game felt a little bit long towards the middle, but quickly got interesting. Seems I was only about 40 minutes from ending the game once I began to feel it was getting long-winded, so that's good. I suppose I'd say it's a decent length then. It took me a little over 4 hours to pass the first time, and about an hour when trying again thanks to the text-skipping (> button).

The in-game character graphics are alright, but the stills are a bit crudely drawn, in a kind of rushed sketch manner. It is this way with the H-scenes too, if you decide to download the patch (which you can find on the game's official website, just save it in the correct folder where the game is). So whether or not those are worth it are up to you. I just did so because I really like trying to pass games as much as I can before tiring of them, and the black screens where the stills are removed were annoying me a bit. Even so, I only saw one side-nipple throughout the entire game .. not sure why Steam keeps trying to censor these things ..

Anyhoo, this game is a good way to kill a couple hours, and it's free. So if you're used to flash games and like mystery-based dating sims or even just .. people sims in general (it is really, really hard to actually get with anyone apparently, soo), this game is worth a read -- although I wish there was a 'meh' button, because I'm a bit of a jerk like that (and have not gotten a truly 'satisfying' ending yet -- good OR bad, hrmm).

Also, as far as I'm aware -- this game isn't really as sad as anyone is saying (unless you get the good ending? even so, it's more .. eh .. stoic or mysterious than sad, really). So if you're the type of person who prides themself on trying to find a really good tearjerker (I know I can be like that sometimes), perhaps this isn't your jam unless you're really sensitive. But I'd still say it's worth a playthrough for the bizarre twist about 2/3rds through. I mean, it's short enough to try.

7/10

reviewText:
Are you tired of Japanese cultural dominance over the foreign animated market? Sick to death of “waifu’s” being all “kawaii”? Are you ready for a different cultural experience that utilizes the distinct art style pioneered by the Japanese yet takes advantage of a different cultural setting? Well then I have good news for you! With “Everlasting Summer” you shall no longer be forcibly confined to the same banal dialogue consisting mostly of an endless stream of chans, kuns and samas; instead immerse yourself in the glory of the Soviet Union with the Communist simulator 2014!

Okay, okay, I jest, but in all seriousness I’d kinda grown tired with the Japan-centric video game industry and the community. That’s a big reason why “Everlasting Summer,” comes as a breath of fresh air. The simple idea of a Young Pioneer camp is, at this point in time, a momento of a bygone era. Therefore, as an American bred on apple pie, baseball and the free market, the presentation, music and overall style of this game comes across as well…highly exotic. Not that I have any real love-lost with the former U.S.S.R. Yet, the uniforms, the Lenin references, the dialogue, district-centers, and the language all carry a flair and charm that’s just so unlike anything I grew up with. Did you know there was rock and roll in the Soviet Union? I certainly didn’t.

There’s a definite sense of nostalgia for the past here. Yet, at the same time it captures the attitudes of a generation transferring to a different way of life. I believe it was in Ulyanas story line that she suggests our main character that sees himself as a savior for the new generation, or something along those lines. Perhaps it says something about modern Russian society in the post-Soviet era. Most all of the endings have the main character exploring some exciting new career path, basically the visit to the past was the epiphany needed to discover what kind of person he wanted to be in the present.

Russia, it can be said, is a nation founded on the idea of active resistance. Moscow is a city on open plain, a city that is not easily defensible; and as we say in social studies, “geography determines destiny.” Much of Russian history involves expansion, extending the borders to defend the capital. This of course leads to all sorts of interesting stereotypes about the Russian people. The only that exists in the modern American historical school, specifically based off of the studies in the Wisconsin school is that the Russians are highly xenophobic, expand their borders when they’re insecure and that their leaders are generally wary of anything beyond their control. I really feel like this story is a product of that environment. Perhaps, unconsciously the writers have portrayed some aspects of the modern mentality of the Russian people. Unsure, a bit insecure, yet ready to find a new identity, somewhere and somehow.

The game isn’t perfect of course. The dialogue is at time superfluous or grammatically incorrect, but this is to be expected when you have a game in translation like this. There are some plot holes and to my knowledge at least one story is left open ended. At least one doesn’t make sense to me, but again, crazy capitalist ‘Murican here.

All in all this is a good VN. Yes the appeal for most will be the girls (yeah there is actually romance in this game, who woulda thunk it right?), especially with…ahem, well with a certain mod installed, but for those that look for something that goes beyond the superficial nature of most modern VN’s, this one is definitely worth your time.
7/10
8/10 for the poker and the Miku ending (seriously what the heck was that?)

reviewText:
*SPOILERS*

9.3/10

To begin with, I wouldn't reccomend this game to anyone who isn't familiar with anime/ managa in general, as some aspects of this game might seem a little too 'lude' or 'ecchi' (and it fact was before steams changes) and will probably stear your attention away from what i find makes this game so special which is its diverse and (to and extent) mind bending plot.

In all honesty, I've never played a VN before; this was my first, but I think I can say with confidence it won't be my last. This game manages to merge and weave a wierd plot together, if you actually have the paitence to get through it all. It starts with a relatable protagonist whos never had any fun factors in his life, always sitting in behind a computer, not really getting anywhere living the hikikomori way, and one day finds himself in an 80's soviet camp, where the population consists of 90% teenage girls with perfect bodies.

The first thing that drew me in was the relatable protagonist, but as I began finishing my first character route, I really wanted to learn more, and it pulled me in. As you progress through each character line, something small gets revealed with each time you play. Little things which leave you clueless about the actual question of where you are, what are you doing here and why can't you leave. These questions actually leave you in the dark unitl you either finish Yulya and Harem's route which, depending on which one you take, determine the outcome of the games plot. I still haven't been able to put the puzzle together of how the two outcomes interconnect or what action made the leap from all the girls coming back into reality or just the one you choose but thats the mistery.

My God then theres the wierd attachments... the feels. As you finish each character route, the protagonist begins to have a relationship of sorts with them, and it felt wrong to completely reject the ones you've become close to for the next character route, especially with Lena considering she felt like Semyon's soul mate, and perhaphs Yulya imo. It's hard to describe how you experience this as Semyon, developing attachments with these characters then forgetting them and then having the bomb shell of remembering each one, realising how impractical it would be to be with any of them. This game makes you feel like you shouldn't have the feels, but you do anyways, maybe because after spending time on the game its hard not to.

Moving on, this game does have a few negatives to it, but very minor ones like some of the english interface is missing or spelt wrong but thats easy to get past (and I think the 27/04/2015 patch has fixed it now). The biggest problem with this game, which isn't really a big one overall, is the way that, in order to finish the game you have to replay it like 6-7 times in order to get each path unlocked to get to Yulya's route, and im not gunna lie, some stages you're going to skip because you've read them like 5 times already, but you'll begin to pick up which parts are differnet with each route you take (NOTE: I wouldn't recommend skipping past any character specific events or any of Yulyas route as even though it may seem like you're going through another loop, Semyon actually begins to have a different approach to things).

Overall, this game is brilliant considering it's free. It makes you feel, and actually has a very nice 'sci-fi' twist to it. Don't just play through once, make it through until the end, as, even though the game may wrap up nicely at the end of a character route (making you think thats the conclusion), make it all the way to understand the bigger picture... to a certain extent.

reviewText:
The fact that this game is completely free of charge, with new content added by zealous, comitted creators and modders alike, this could easily get an auto-reccomend.

The strange tale of Semyon in the equivalent of the scouts in 1980's Russia is a story about deep personal connections between himself and the various young women in the game, though sometimes compared to its contemporaries, it can feel shallow, and the art could definitely use some minor improvements here and there.

I wanted to get the negatives out of the way, because there is quite a bit to love here. The various romance options have for the most part unique and interesting personalities. Unlike many of its contemporaries, its difficult to pidgeonhole any of the characters into a particular trope (though some do come close,) and the characters feel three dimensional and fairly dynamic. I feel like the inclusion of the secret endings a bit... anachronistic and not fitting with the mood, but by the time you go for all the endings in this game, you'll be invested enough in the story of everyone attending the camp, including the main character.

Overall though, well written, the characters are memorable, and its long enough to let the story breathe and short enough to not make it feel like a slog to get the endings, which add pieces to the story at large.

Once again, completely free of charge with modders and talented, devoted devs adding new content. I would say if you're on the fence, go for it and try it out.

reviewText:
This game shouldn't be free.
You should pay to Soviet Game for this wonderful trip.
I mean, what other game has HATSUNE FREAKING MIKU as an unique route?
That aside, the story is top notch. I'm pretty sure that almost everyone can connect with
the main character, even if not fully, because his life is the sum of most modern age elements.
After a twist of destiny, our dear protagonist ends up in a Soviet camp, and the only thing that's for sure are the increasing amount of questions.
And believe me, the real answers only begin after you've explored each other route, at least the ones that aren't blocked.
I won't say that all the routes are great, some are lackluster, some are real pieces of art (Miku route will take you on a wild ride, you will want to get off Ms Miku's wild ride), and others will only left you with a bittersweet taste.
You can make a lot of this game, or only see it as another Visual Novel. It's up to you.
Also, it's free! There are HUNDREDS, if not THOUSANDS of bad Visual Novels out there.
Even the art is pretty good, and that's A LOT.
11/10 would take the Ms Miku's wild ride again and again.

Also, DON'T TRUST ANYONE. Don't lose sight of your Cutlets.

reviewText:
My heart is broken....and every game interacting with my emotions is a good game for me.

I really wouldn't have thought that I would spent 8 hours over 3 Days with this.
And that's a good thing!

Coming to my overall experience.
I was sceptical since this was my first visual novel period. I actually wanted to try it and started with this one because it costs not a single dollar and the reviews were pretty good.
The first hour might have lost me but I stayed and it drew me somehow into its world (get it? because the protagonist also gets into another world").
I liked the characters and the overall sound (ambient and music). Since I knew
date: there would be several endings I really started working hard for  one I liked most. It actually worked out pretty well for some time. I mean the character at some points is a bit dumb with his decisions but most decisions I actually did myself got me closer to my goal....you know...getting that one girl you like best.\nNow at the end I'm a bit surprised and heartbroken.....As you might have figured out
recommended: I did not really get the ending which I really wanted. All my work was for nothing. And I really like
hoursPlayed:
that this depresses me. This vn gets to my nerves and actually makes me regret some decisions.
Not many games have touched my heart as much recently nor have other stories in movies or books ever done so.

So about the visual novel itself. You cannot really argue about since the price it is free to play.
I guess it was part of a freetime project and most likely very few developers.
However
voteText:
there are some things to point out:
First of all I already mentioned the very decent sound. There was nothing too special but it always fits the situation.
The backgrounds are well drawn and are somehow in contrast to the characters. I did not really have problems with that but it definitly gave me a bad first impression since they might be the weakest part of the game.
Also having minor translation problems but meals and people are explained so you don't have to google words you might not know.

What else is there left to say? I'm eager to get my ending of desire and also trying out other visual novels thanks to Everlasting Summer.
Of course
helpfulPercent: it's not really a game
votesHelpful: but a nice story with good accent on the characters and as for me those were very welld spent 8 hours. They probably should make a remake with polished graphics and sell it.....I would buy it then."

reviewText:
Negative reviews say that the story is boring and the characters are badly designed, or too typical.
I'd say they are looking wrong way. The game has beautiful atmosphere - music and backgrounds are its forte. The plot is good, but not with the choices and plot twists, but with short catchphrases, that makes tremble you heart, or makes you cry while rolling on the floor. Yes, it looks like some sort of book, but it is a book - a visual novel.
Also, I'm denying that there is bad character design. Often you can get a bad end just doing something innocent, but then realizing that was predictable wrong choice. This leads to breach in your relationship and then she... but this is a spoiler, sorry.
I see here some reviews from gamers who played this just one time for the end. I say that after you get good ends with all girls (even Miku), you will get another one, more prettier in some aspects. I hope this force you to get all the ends.
tl;dr: Worth you 4 hours (game length). Your 8 hours. You 20 hours.

reviewText:
Definitely delivers more than your usual japanese dating-sim VN.

I generally enjoy VNs as media, but I find most of them lackluster and shallow, very few of them employ the capabilities of media format to deliver the touching story. This one - does. It makes you care about what happens on the screen. And read hour after hour, going into the night... Immersion and story flow - it's about what good visual novel should be, and it's all here in place.

The game so much excites me that I'm feeling like becoming a fan and writing a hype review... Better don't, since the Everlasting Summer already got a lot of hype and it's share of fanboys. But even if I'd try to be unbiased, I wouldn't score the game less than great". Certainly
date: it has it's downfalls - like too-pretentious plot
recommended: resulting in plot holes and anti-climax ending (I'm greatly disappointed in otherwise great Yulya route!) - but it keeps an overall good quality and
hoursPlayed: what is more important
voteText: keeps you ♥♥♥♥ing care. It's definitely not the best visual novel out there
helpfulPercent: but also definitely the outstanding one.\n\nP.S. I really like the music."

reviewText: I would write about how great a game Everlasting Summer is, with its stunning artwork, great music, original story, intriguing setting and great visual novel gameplay style, driving the novelistic plot along. But, while all these things hold true, it's been more than an entertaining experience for me, like games generally are. Everlasting Summer has adversely changed my philosophies on life. Each ending offeres a new perspective, or multiple, on so many different things, giving many aspects of life a new look for me. The protagonist is rather similar to me, or where I would generally view myself a few years from now. A boring, repetitive, hopeless grind of life. However, after playing through just all the bad" endings and Miku's
date: I can feel myself taking a new look on existence in general and feel long-subdued emotions rising. If the depressing
recommended: bad endings have stirred this change in me
hoursPlayed: I can only imagine what the rest will do for me. Everlasting Summer is beyond being a great visual novel for me. It's offered me a new light on a lot of aspects of life."

reviewText: Everlasting Summer is a visual novel. It's set in a Russian pioneer camp called “Sovinok.” The main character you play as ends up there after falling asleep on a bus and somehow wakes up outside the camp.  The camp is set before the main character is even born so you can imagine how confused he is. The game is set over 7 days at the camp and in that 7 days you will get to know other pioneers at the camp. After you “beat” the game you will have an ending depending on the choices you made during the 7 days. The choices you make effect the other characters in the game and how they behave towards you. It’s a really fun visual novel and you should defiantly replay it to try to get different endings.

reviewText:
I consider myself a fan of visual novels. Not just for the images, but because the stories are often intricately made and well written. Everlasting Summer is well written, translated quite well from Russian, and has some wonderful backgrounds and characters.

The story is complex, a bit confusing if you don't read it carefully. But it's a nice story, none the less. The music is fitting for the game, and relaxing enough to remind me of my own summer vacations. Even the backgrounds are well made, holding details that make it very fitting.

Yet it does have some faults. Not every scene matches the last, and it's obvious where different artist drew characters and scenes. But that's to be expected to some degree since this was made on a forum. The translations are good, but sometimes hinder the story since some of the sentences aren't perfect" english.

Overall
date: I highly suggest this to anyone wanting to try out a visual novel for the first time. The fact that it's free makes it easier to pick up and play. So my final score for it is : 4.5/5"

reviewText: This is my first attempt at a visual novel and I've only done four endings so I'll update as I progress. Firstly, this is an amazing game, it looks beautiful, the soundtrack is thrilling, the characters are well written and the plot it really interesting. I has huge replayability, it's about 4-5 hours per ending, well at least for the two I've done so far. It was orignally released in Russian and the translation is a bit off here and there but nothing that you can't understand from what's going in the surrounding context. Overall, it's throughly enjoyable and I'd recommend this to anyone whether an experiend visual novelist or a beginner.\n\nHappy camping Pioneers!
